reviewText: We don't have a DVR so we have enjoyed watching this series via Amazon Prime Instant Video!  Show on FX is waaay too long because of ads and airs at strange times!  Anyway, my husband and I have both enjoyed the dramady!  Yes, it is drama but, with a little comic relief in the mix!  It is definitely adult in content for the language, sex, and violence.  However, the story lines and some of the characters, make for good entertainment.  The one drawback as we see it:  filmed on location in obviously DRY California, not the lush Bluegrass hills of KENTUCKY where it supposedly takes place!!

reviewText: My Mom had been recommending this show since it's initial release. Of course being my Mom I thought she was nuts, but from the opening scene I was sucked it in. I've been binge watching, knocking out a season every couple of days. I think Timothy Olyphant is great, but Walter Goggins really steals the show. I loved his work on The Shield and I can not recommend it more. I like the crossover of the characters from The Shield, SoA, and Deadwood. Once again this is must see for fans of this genre.

reviewText: My husband had asked if we could watch this together. When my husband suggests something he likes, I usually absolutely hate it or I love it. I was a little reluctant as always but I said sure, kinda hoping he'd forget about my promise. But he never does. So when it was released on DVD he of course wanted it, so I bought it for him for Valentine's Day. We sat down one evening last week to watch and after one episode, I was hooked. I was so surprised to like it - I think I may even like it more than he does.The show stars Timothy Olyphant as U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens, who after undergoing some conflict in Miami, Florida, is reassigned to his home state of Kentucky. And also, he is not exactly very happy about it.I could talk about it all day, but there are a lot of other reviewers here who I'm sure could and will tell you the same thing: It's a good show. One of the best new shows I've seen in quite awhile. Check it out!
summary: I was very surprised! - in a great way
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: A favorite show.  I always enjoy Timothy Olyphant, and the stories are interesting.  Some of the regular characters are good guys and bad guys.

reviewText: This show is somehow both very traditional and yet the most original program in television. Raylan seems so easy-going but is also driven. And his nemisis, Boyd Crowder is also multi-layered, who is so chameleon like that you are never sure you have a goid grasp of him. It is the most involving show on telwvision and benefits from multiple viewings.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: My husband and I got interested in this show thru Amazon reviews.  I reaserched it on Amazon after receiving email notices about it from them.  We have never seen it on TV and do not want to.  We have season I and season II and watch them often.  We have season III preordered.  We will continue to buy them as long as they are made. We love this show.  It is well done, well written and well acted.  The hillbilly humor cracks us up because we know that there are people and situations like that in everyday life.  Rylan fears nothing and no one, but the show is true to reality so he makes mistakes and gets his butt kicked from time to time. Great balance of humor and drama.  High praises to all involved with this show.  Please keep doing what you do.  It's appreciated.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I have not been hooked by a show since the Sopranos. This show is very well written, the hip bluegrass music is a treat. reviewText: Any fan of Elmore Leonard will like the early episodes and the quirky characters, but it soon devolves into a formula as the TV writers mechanically get the job down to a reasonable work week.  Too bad.  Like any series it is vaguely addictive and I watched the whole thing (3 seasons), but the bubblegum lost its flavor on the bedpost overnight.I watched all three (free) seasons and this is becoming a pattern - watch the episodes until I get to the $1.99.  None have yet been sufficiently interesting to entice me into continuing and I am wondering if the later episodes will ever become free.  At this rate, I should pretty much exhaust Amazon Prime in ab out another 6 mos.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Based on an Elmore Leonard character (in fact, if the credits are to be believed, the entire series is based on a short story about said character), the series follows Raylan Givens, a U.S. Marshall who's bootstrapped himself out of Harlan County, where he grew up with an abusive, criminal father and a future doomed to working in the mines.  After shooting a drug cartel hitman, Raylan is transferred away from a post in Miami and back to Lexington, KY, where he's hip-deep in crime in, you guessed it, Harlan County, the place he least wants to belong . . .but where he can operate better than anyone else--he's accepted.  Timothy Olyphant is amazing in the title role, a man keeping a tight grip on his emotions and his manners--he's very polite, even when threatening to shoot you.  All of the acting in this series is first rate, especially Walton Goggins as Raylan's childhood friend Boyd, whose yen for a spiritual life wars with his genius for criminal activity.  I haven't even touched on the excellent actresses in the cast, or the tangled romantic snarls, but let this exchange suffice: Raylan: "What do you make of a man who divorces a woman, THEN gets her pregnant, THEN wonders if maybe they should move in together?" Boyd: "Well,now, Raylan, you're talkin' to a man who's sleeping with his dead brother's widow and murderess, so if you're lookin' for someone to cast stones at you on this matter, I think you've picked the wrong sinner."
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Quite simply, I like Justified because these are the places and people of my youth.  Moved away long decades ago (military), and retired out West, but when I hear those accents and the Hill patois language, I can't help but watch.Gripes?  Realism, for one.  If any U.S. Marshall or other LEO shot as many folk as Raylan Givens does, he/she would get a one-way ticket out of law enforcement...just because of the liability concerns.Second, I do get tired of the stereotypes.  Heck, even the lawyers judges are painted as complete fools, and EVERY local LEO is ALWAYS corrupt.  There's some truth behind the stereotypes, of course, but a lot less these days than in past.Third, I just plain get tired of the frequent skin, intensely suggestive sexual dialogue, far too many naked butts, and just plain too much cussing.  I'd much rather they cleaned the series up a bit.  No, not completely...it is Harlan County, after all...but all too often such devices are used as stunts and filler to gloss over plot holes and miscues.  Come on, writers, you can do better than that.I would caution anyone with teens or kids to NOT watch the show with them...and make sure they aren't watching it behind your back.  The TV-MA rating is fully deserved for this series, and only mature adults should be watching.Finally, a plea to all you non-Hill people out there:  take Justified with a couple of huge grains of salt.  Don't make the mistake of confusing accents with intelligence.  Don't assume every hillbilly has their own still up the holler.  Southern charm and hospitality is famous...but so is Southern retribution for those who insult our ways.  Tread carefully in what you say about us, if you ever want to be our friends.
summary: Interesting Show, Too Much Skin & Language

reviewText: When I realized that Timothy Olyphant who played the sheriff in Deadwood was in this show, I decided to watch it.  I liked Deadwood so I hoped that I would like this too.  I have only watched 2 episodes.  Maybe it's just me, but I felt like I was watching Deadwood in a modern day setting except less interesting.  Mr. Olyphant seemed to be the same character.  Same facial expression, same attitude and I could swear he is wearing the same hat. Is he really going to shoot every criminal in the show and be "justified" in doing it?  And wasn't Walter Goggins in Deadwood too?  Maybe the problem is that I was really waiting for Deadwood to come back for another season.  This isn't it.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I got into Justified late, I started around the end of season three.  It is a great show that just keeps getting better.  I had really wanted to start from the beginning because one of the people from The Shield was behind the show and Walton Goggins is in the show.  Well this series does not disappoint.  With bad guys that have their good points to the tortured relationship between the main character and his father.  It is an interesting show that will get you hooked.  I highly recommend seeing it from the beginning.  It makes more sense that way.  I feel better now I know some of the back stories.  Watch this you won't be sorry.

reviewText: This is pulp fiction. It's gritty and hard; creepy and unafraid. I just finished the first season and need to digest it before moving on to two. It gives you something to think about even if it's dark. The characters are courageous and ruthless, some are flawed deep to the soul and still good. Some are evil. Some we just don't know. And on top of it all, it's a good story well written and executed. What more can we ask for?
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Love this show!! It has been recommended to me by several friends and I must say that at first I was uninterested. Cops, guns, low life's... Don't we have enough of that in real life. I will say that I have changed my mind. Good writing, very much like the character development. Production design is the worst part of the show, same with the in car camera shots, but once to get past that, the characters keep you engaged. The acting is wonderful and well cast! Must say, I am  pleasantly surprised, and now reading the books the series is based on.

reviewText: The pilot was exciting. The few next episodes were fun. But with time, Justified lacks the ability to build continuity as well as proper secondary characters. Ultimately, episodes are disconected from each others, and despite a few attempts in building more complex plots, most of them do not survive more than a couple episodes, leading to an endless repetition of the same scheme: new plot, new characters, Raylan arrives, get in charge (of all kind of s****, I wasn't aware that marshall duties were so extensive), new character emerge and most likely get killed or disappear before the end, like in an aim and shoot shooting range. Is it always justified? From a scenario point of view, I disagree, and can't help to find the redundancy plain boring.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: The perfect amount of sexy snarkiness, if there is such a word. Not to unpredictable, but sometimes you just know what's going to happen due to the type of show it is. I highly recommend this series to anyone.

reviewText: I was really looking forward to seeing this show, I was at the movies and a preview of Justified came on, I immediately set my cell phone to alert me at the time and day that the show was to air. I love this show... but, I love Timothy Olyphant so much that I could sit and watch an hour of him drinking a glass of water and I would give it 5 stars.Seriously, the show is good, the whole concept of the US Marshall that is not gun-shy at all is pretty funny. The transformation of Boyd from white supremisist killer to "MAN OF GOD" is great, and Boyd's relationship with his father is pretty cool. I like the prison scene when you first meet Boyd's dad -that was awsome.Over all I thought this show was great and I look forward to season 2, I am definately buying this on DVD. The last episode of Season 1, WOW that was worth it all.  MAN I cant wait to see how it all continues.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Olyphant and Goggins are great together. In terms of story structure, it seems like they are trying to expand the one-hour TV episode into a more spiral story structure, like the HBO shows, and I like it. I like they are trying to do more with this show. A writer I admire pointed out that, in a show like Treme, New Orleans is, herself, a character and this show could do a bit more of that with Kentucky. I love the Hillbilly characters because, let's face it, these people exist just as much of the good folks of Kentucky too.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I love Justified, and I love Raylan Givens.  He's a real man with human frailties.  Justified reminds me of the old Western movies and television series.  Gotta love that hat, and those boots!!  The series gives me an insight of a culture that is not familiar to me.  The characters are believable, and it's easy to get into the drama.  There are always surprises..little twists and turns, so it's never predictable or boring.

reviewText: This show will remind you of some of the best of Clint Eastwood's early work. The lead is convincing and pulls off a fairly compelling characterization of the lone lawman who stands for truth, justice and the American way even though he is conflicted by living in an 'end justifies the means' world.  Good TV!

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This is in my opinion, the best scripted series on television. Raylon walks a blurred legal line and is so totally human, you can't help but love him, even when he messes up, which he does. And Boyd Crowder is about the nastiest guy around. What a great cast, can't wait for more.

reviewText: GREAT show!  So many interesting characters.  Highly recommend for people with a dry sense of humor who can handle violence as well.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I really like the quality of the acting.  The characters are like able despite mostly being on the wrong side of the law.  At least some of the time.  I like that Raylan (Timothy Olyphant) is not indestructible, takes the odd beating or two, and doesn't effortlessly win all the time.  I like the stories, the gritty setting, and the flow of the whole series.  The here and now stories and the back stories that come to light as the season carries on.  Definitely a good one to catch if you haven't already seen it.

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I don't care for 90% of the cop or crime drama shows on TV, don't like westerns, and think folks put too much emphasis on certain actors-having said that, I love this show!Casting did an excellent job finding the right actors for respective parts, and the multiple stories (spanning the entire season and within each episode) are all excellent. Season 1 was so good, I had to wonder how long they could keep it up-looks like they made it to about episode 5 of the new season before things went a bit off track.EDIT: I watched season 2 again (nuttin' else on TV!) and for some reason, I thought the second half of season 2 episodes were better than I remember `em being first time around!I also finally got around to watching all the extras on the DVDs-`bout all of `em were pretty good!I've been so disappointed in movies lately that I rarely go (they confuse motion with action), but one thing I really miss is soundtracks. Newer movies went south long before the soundtracks-season 1 has a great soundtrack, and I don't care for country music! I had to go hunting for the music, but here's a few I've found, all of which I think can be sampled at Amazon mp3 site (episode title in parenthesis):Say Ho by Phase 73 (Fire in the Hole-opening scene)Someday I'll Be Forgiven For This by Justin Townes Earle (Fire in the Hole)It Took a Long Time by Koko Taylor (Fire in the Hole)Sans Soleil by Miike Snow (Fire in the Hole-closing scene)Castleneck by Cliff Wagner & The Old #7 (Riverbrook-it's the convict band's number)Ten Million Slaves by Otis Taylor (Blowback-closing scene)You Left Me Lefty by United Steelworkers of Montreal (Blind Spot)Stand By Your Man by Tammy Wynette (Hatless)Homesick by Ryan Kickland (Veterans)It Took a Long Time by Koko Taylor (Fathers and Sons)You'll Never Leave Harlan Alive by Brad Paisley (Bulletville-closing scene)SEASON 2Little Lovin' by Lissie (music from season 2 trailer)Heathen's Kiss by Horsefeathers (The Moonshine War-surreal opening scenes montage)Harlan County Line by Dave Alvin (The I of the Storm)Through It All by Leftover Cuties (Blaze of Glory-ending chase scene!)Anabelle by Gillian Welch (Reckoning-surreal funeral scene montage)I gave season 1 to a relative that normally would not give a show like this a second glance, and they blew through all 13 episodes in short order!
summary: Best thing I've seen on TV in a LONG time!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This series has the twist and turns of the Nip Tuck series that I had grown to love. And the fact that it takes place in Kentucky doesn't hurt. between seeing the main character making mistakes and finding lovable qualities in the villains it will keep you watching just to see what crazy things the characters get into next. And as crazy as the plot is at times it never strays far from the truth. life in Appalachia really is that juxtaposed.

reviewText: I watch an episode at a time when running at home on my treadmill.  The show is a nicely done melding of cowboy tropes with modern police procedurals, topped by a sprinkling of bluegrass/downhome Kentucky flavoring.  It has a sense of humor and reasonably interesting plots, and a star who is definitely eye candy.  The HD version looks and sounds great.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Several people kept telling me about how good a series named Justified is. So, earlier this year when Amazon had a special on DVDs, I decided to purchase Season #1 along with many other purchases. One night, few weeks ago, I decided to check the series out on FX-TV and I must say, I became hooked on what I quickly learned was Season #4 which just ended. What a great show! Because I was so anxious to learn all about the characters and storylines that I had already missed, I IMMEDIATELY watched Season #1 (bought earlier) which I just finished and I must say that I am so outdone at how great this series is! I just ordered Seasons #2 and #3 which I now wish I had ordered before I finished Season #1. The actors and the writing are superb. Just when you think it cannot get any better, it does!!! I sincerely hope Season #4 is released by the time I finish Season #3. IMO, this is one of the most entertaining series on TV. As a former Chicago L.E.O.(Law Enforcement Officer as referred to in the series), I am not too impressed with many "good guy/bad guy" cop series. So I repeat. I am outdone at just how good Justified is and highly recommend everyone who likes action, reality, humor, etc. to watch Justified and get thoroughly Satisfied!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: The  acting is good. The show rides the line between humor and drama. Interesting characters. I like it a lot.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This television series is full of great characters.  I like that Givens (Stephen Oliphant) is kind of a mess.  Always in some kind of trouble or at least trouble finds him a lot, but he's not over glorified or over done.  Just a US Marshall with maybe a chip on his shoulder about life and who also happens to draw a pistol like Doc Holiday.  So you might say he's a modern day gun slinger.  The characters that develop around Givens are great. Love this show. If you are looking for another series to get into, definitely give this one a try!!
summary: Modern Day Gun Slinger - good stuff
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: After watching Justified Season 1, you cannot wait to go on and watch Seasons 2-4. These actors are fantastic but more than that, the dialogue is fresh, witty, clever, sometimes hilarious. There are many "dramas" and cop shows on TV but none as well written and slyly humorous as Justified. I cannot wait for Season 5 this January on TV!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Season one starts with a bang and hits the ground running.  Unfortunately, it looses steam somewhere along the line.  But, once the writers go back to the Elmore Leonard style of wry wit, things pick up again.  In the following seasons, the ball just continues to roll right along getting better and better. Timothy Olyphant gives Raylan just the right amount of laconic anger.  Good show

reviewText: This is one of the best shows I've ever watched on television.  I think this is drama in the class of OZ, the Wire or Breaking Bad.  Good company.  The lead is a real star, supporting cast are engaging yet  terribly flawed.  Walter Goggins is the best bad guy and most conflicted character outside Breaking Bad.  It's just a fun show, it's rare to watch a production fairly portray southern rednecks, this one has them down.  Warts, mullets, authentic twang and all.  I love it.

reviewText: To be fair I think if one followed this show with dedication it would probably get a higher ranking. I really like Olyphant as an actor and it is disappointing how he always gets type caste as a law enforcer when he could do more. The premier had his character being transferred from Florida to Kentucky (his old stomping ground) after a controversial shooting of a thug in a restaurant (basically to coll off). From there out he is involved in the wild-side of Kentucky- running into old friends and lovers. The show does a disservice in the way it portrays Kentucky-really one-sided (Neo-Nazi's, drug addicts, drop-outs, farmer daughter types, and white lightening makers) . I am sure there are a wider variety of people living there.I might watch this again.

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This is one show that lives up to the hype. Its good enough to be on HBO and you even see actors from HBO series like Hung: The Complete First Season and Deadwood: The Complete Series [Blu-ray], appearing in different episodes along with the series star (who was in Deadwood). And even though its not my kind of music, the blue grass you hear in the series  is great too. This character was created by one of the best crime writers, Elmore Leonard, who is active in production of Justified. He brings a western sense of justice to the modern day U.S. Marshall's service. Raylan Givens is the kind of law enforcement officer you want patrolling your neck of the woods. He isn't afraid of anything and has a keen nose that puts him in the right place at the right time more times than not. While the coincidences in the series aren't too believable, the situations often elicit a chuckle. The humor in the series is another factor that keeps me coming back for more. For instance at the end of season 3, a bad guy gets his arm cut off and later Raylan tells someone that at his office his fellow deputys like to say he "disarmed him". Corny but funny. Refreshing series, wish there were more like it.The streaming PQ and AQ was very good, as good was watching on Dish.
summary: Perfect Blend Of Action and Suspense
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Excellent show so far.  Entertaining without being too dramatic and for a change the person in charge is a man!!  Most cop, lawyer, medical etc shows today the woman is in charge and the man is the idiot tagging along.  Not sure why the networks decided this change was the way to go but at least this one isn't that way as of yet.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: We started watching this year (season 4) and wondered what had happened to lead up to where the series is at now.  The usual predictability is offset by the twist of events that unfolds during an episode.  So far, it has kept us interested and ready to watch the next one as soon as it comes on. The various bad guy characters mesh moral and immoral into a weird sense of illegal right and wrong with a bit of hill country idiocy and brilliance thrown in. The good guys seem to be savvy enough to be real humans instead of the slick minds and tech advanced super shows that are so popular and absolutely everywhere on TV right now.  A very different cops and robbers show indeed.
summary: This has been fun to watch

reviewText: Raylan Givens, the (anti-) hero of Justified is both similar to and different from the crop of bad-guys-we-root-for that have sprung up in this new golden age of television. Unlike Tony Soprano, Raylan is ostensibly a good guy. Unlike Walter White, Raylan isn't driven by desperation. And unlike Dexter Morgan, Raylan isn't (quite) a sociopath.Raylan is an old-fashioned cowboy living in the modern world. He has a complicated relationship with his past (conflicts arising from his criminal father, backwoods community, and old grudges drive the plot of many episodes) and his success as a US Marshall is tarnished by his willingness to indulge in justice tempered with just enough vigilantism that it makes his superiors nervous. He is less an anti-hero than a capital 'G' good guy - a man who will not hesitate to do violence for good reasons.In that sense, Justified is less a drama about an anti-hero and more an old-fashioned (and deeply romantic) heroic saga. More than anything, Raylan reminds me of Stephen King's Gunslinger - a man driven by a morality at once completely honorable and relentlessly unforgiving, even of those he loves.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I just finished "The Shield" (all seven seasons) and worried that I might not find anything as fun or as good for my occasional bouts of insomnia.  No fears.  This show is it.  I have always liked Tim Olyphant, but I really like him in this.  And Walton Goggins is a new favorite actor (after seeing him so brilliantly portray Shane in "The Shield.")  This is going to be another binge-show for me, I can tell.  I almost wish I would get a bad cold or flu just so I could justify lying in bed to watch episode after episode.  But alas, I am perfectly well and have other things to do. My newest guilty pleasure.

reviewText: First I saw the billboards for the coming second season. Never heard of it. After much review I took a chance with the first season on BluRay. My wife and I knew Timothy Olyphant from Hitman and couldn't imagine this fellow starring lead in his own dramatic show about a lawman gone home. Boy we were wrong. Tim is delightful and a natural, reminding you of a younger Tommy Lee Jones. He plays the role of the US Marshall without bravado or over the top southern machismo. And what else is wonderful is that you are getting to know him a little bit better every episode. Not everything that makes him tick is obvious nor simple and that's just fine that they are taking the time to flesh him out.We are waiting now for season 2 to hit blu ray because the stories were so great the first season we just had marathon viewing of the discs and intend to do the same for season 2. Definitely a winning show. I hope its here to stay a while as some decent series have been getting the axe right and left as of late.
summary: Great show.Tim Olyphant shows his acting chops.

reviewText: Wow, this show is surprisingly good. I was actually about half way through the first season and I was thinking to myself "How is it possible this show is so well written?" when I noticed, for the first time, in the opening credits that the show is based on works by Elmore Leonard. I do not mean to detract from the fabulous job the screen writer's have done adapting this for television but I am sure it helped a bit to have a solid base to work from. I admit, I have never read any of Leonard's books, though I have heard they are very well written, but I have seen a few of his movies, and there are two things that you can count on from Leonard: great characters and great dialogue. This show has both (more on that in a moment).In a way, the premise of the show sounds kind of silly to me. Essentially it is an attempt to transplant the old Western, with the fast drawing gunslinger, into modern times. The main character, a deputy U.S. Marshal named Raylan, has just been transferred back to his hometown in Kentucky after shooting someone under somewhat suspicious circumstances in Florida. Raylan is a fast draw and he gets himself into quite a few old Western style stand-off  situations. Like I said, that sounds a little bit silly on the face of it (do they still train Marshals to draw quickly and shoot without looking?) but it actually works really well. They do not get ridiculous with it. All of the quick draw situations Raylan finds himself in are believable. There are no high noon shootouts on Main Street.The show has a great cast of characters. The first season follows a story arc based around the Crowder family. The Crowder family are a bunch of criminals from Raylan's hometown and they make excellent and really interesting villains. Boyd Crowler, in particular, is a really interesting character, and the actor, Walton Goggins, does a superb job playing him. Raylan's father is also a very interesting character. There is a very strained relationship between Raylan and his father and the show handles it well. Usually shows like this run into problems dealing with strained family relationships. They wind up manufacturing a bunch of repetitive drama (the same arguments over and over) and then get very sentimental with it (the emotional blowup and reunion). This show avoids all of that. There were no cringe worthy scenes in this show, the kind that often feel like they come straight out of an introductory psychology textbook. That is surprisingly rare. Even some of my favorite shows have cringe worthy scenes here and there. This show, at least in the first season, which is all I have watched so far, had none.The show also has really well written dialogue. I watch a lot of procedurals and the dialogue on procedurals usually leaves a lot to be desired. A lot of shows, I think, wind up sacrificing quality for quantity. Shows that put out 24 episodes a season always feel a bit like they were made in a factory to me. The same scenes, with minor variations, show up in every episode. The dialogue is extremely repetitive (the same arguments over and over), a lot of the dialogue is just exposition ("so, here we are, at the gangsters hideout"), or filler. I am not sure if it is because they only have 13 episodes a season, or if they are using some of Leonard's original dialogue, or if they just have really talented screenwriter's, but the dialogue in this first season was really good.Another thing I appreciate about the show is that it often goes against cliches. I will just give one example of what I mean. There is a scene in one of the episodes where Raylan is drinking in the bar. We are far enough into the show to know that Raylan knows how to handle himself. There are two guys in the bar talking real loud, making crude remarks about some woman, and Raylan decides to confront them. This is a really familiar trope and most people, including me, immediately have certain expectations about where things are heading. The situation escalates and they decide to take things outside. This is where the two guys realize they picked a fight with the wrong person, right? Wrong. The show totally surprised me by having the two guys win the fight. Raylan gets beat up.That might seem like a really minor thing but very few shows would have been willing to have their hero lose a fight like that. You are never supposed to perceive any weakness in the hero. Not only is that unrealistic but it is boring. I really appreciated that this show was willing to frustrate the viewer's expectations. That was just one scene, and it was not all that important for the overall plot, but it was, to me, a great example of why I think this show is a cut above most of the television shows I watch. The show avoids cliche. The characters are not cliche, the dialogue is not cliche, and the stories are not cliche. I am not sure how this show slipped by me for four seasons, but I am glad I found it eventually.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I don't want to visit Kentucky – especially the rural areas – because I know I'll be shot dead by either the local criminals or the Federal Marshall.Raylan Givens is a charming man, and I find myself enchanted by him and his shenanigans. Like my other favorite series, Breaking Bad, this is a show I have learned to enjoy no matter how despicable the characters are.I recommend it highly to anyone who enjoys a good "Western" in a modern setting.

reviewText: i had only heard about this show when season two started. i hadn't heard a thing about this show at all. i went ahead and bought season 1 on blu ray and started watching it. this is a great show, and all i have seen are the first three episodes. there is a boat load of swearing that can't go on the main networks, but still, i give this high marks.it follows a U S marshall that got screwed over when he shot a man about to shoot him. he gets sent back home to work and the place has changed since he's been gone. he seems to be the lone marshall cleaning up the town now with a little help from a few of his co-workers,pleanty of humor to keep this from being a dark "hicksville" show and pleanty of action too. very good show

reviewText: After viewing the duo of Joel Kinnaman and Mireille Enos in "The Killing", Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul in "Breaking Bad" and Robert Taylor and Lou Diamond Phillips in "Longmire", "Justified" pales in comparison. Timothy Olyphant and Erica Tazel are outdone by Walton Goggins and Joelle Carter which was probably not the writers' intention. The stoic-faced Olyphant simply does not possess the skill level of Goggins, Kinnaman, Cranston, or Taylor. Also, petite Erica Tazel as Rachel is miscast. I could believe Queen Latifah in that role.
summary: Not as good as some other series
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: After the disappearance of LOST, The Shield and (prematurely) The Wire and The Unit from our small screens, I was actively looking out for something of similar quality to appear. I think I have found it...I first heard about Justified on a forum I belong to and it intrigued me immediately. I decided to take a gamble and purchase the first season (the local satellite is already on the second season and I'd missed Season one) from Amazon.Well, I have not been disappointed. I was already a fan of Timothy Olyphant but it is the presence of Elmore Leonard, one of the great dialogue writers of the crime genre, and the fine writing of the show that really makes it worthwhile. The dialogue is superb, echoing the sly genius of Leonard's novels, without attempting to be a lame copy of it. It is also very funny.The characters are keenly sketched, the locations are well chosen and the fascinating, incestuous culture of the Kentucky backwoods adds a rich, smoky texture to the whole deal, like good BBQ chased down by a fine, rare bourbon.Of course the real cherry on the cake is Walton Goggins. Any fan of The Shield knows the skills this fine actor has and his Boyd character is one of the real delights of the series. Walton has really come into his own here.I just hope the show garners enough of a fanbase so that the networks dont consider cancelling it prematurely. I have a feeling it is only going to get better and better as it spools out.
summary: A pleasure to savour, like a fine, rare bourbon

reviewText: It is easy to get hooked on this TV series about a US Marshal that is transferred back to his home state of Kentucky after he has a questionable shooting in Florida.  The storylines are great, and the cast is super.  Add in excellent directing and locations and you have a winning combination.  Although several of the stories involve local crime and politics, there are many about a wide variety of other things that impact most people at work and home.  The main theme is how rival families struggle to gain power in the county and state.  Plenty of intrique and drama unfolds every episode.  Once I started watching them I could not stop and I watched all four seasons in about three days.  I highly recommend it.CA Luster
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This series is just plain fun to watch.  Raylan Gibbons, played by good-looking Timothy Olyphant, is with the US Marshall Service. reviewText: This is about a U.S. Marshall who goes back home to Kentucky to fight crime, still with the US Marshall's Office, after killing a bad guy down in Miami in a good old fashioned gun draw, just like in the Old West.  Our hero even wears a cowboy hat in the showdown, overlooking Miami beach no less!  This show has really stirring stories created by excellent writers, the hallmark of any really good tv series.The acting is first rate too with Timothy Olyphant from DEADWOOD in the lead marshall role and Walton Scoggins, last seen in THE SHIELD as Shane, a bad cop, as the down home bad guy.  Scoggins does his usual incredible job.  This time he is a bad guy who has caught the fever of old time religion which makes for some of the most absurdist scenes ever seen in crime shows. Olyphant is a complex hero who makes gigantic mistakes along the way but still wants to be in his heart of hearts that Gary Cooper figure in HIGH NOON.The show even has a terrific theme song, LONG HARD TIMES TO COME by the New York City based Gangstagrass, using an oddly appealing combination of blue grass and rap music.

reviewText: I first saw Timothy Olyphant in Deadwood and in my opinion he stole the show.  He was dominant in every scene where he appeared and there were some pretty intense scenes!  Deadwood's only flaw was way too much lewd language but that is another subject.The next time I saw Olyphant was a small role in the Damages series but he was wasted there.  Nevertheless, he stood out.  Being interested in this young actor, I sought more information and the found the highly recommended series "Justified" which I purchased.  Am very entertained with this series and Olyphant delivers once again ... credible, sardonic at times and very engaging.  Timothy reminds me of a young Eastwood, but he has more nuances to him which is gratifying.  Hope to see more series in the future for him.
summary: OLYPHANT IS AS GOOD AS CLINT EASTWOOD!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Sometimes cardboard characters are satisfyingly entertaining; sometime stereotypes can earn grudging respect. But Justified earns very little credits in any category other than atmosphere. I'm sorry about that. A lot of effort went in to making this feel like a regional piece of cultural insight. It really isn't. Having lived there for years, I'd say the bad guys are not nearly mean enough to seem real, and the good guys fall short of being conflicted enough to ask themselves meaningful questions. Everything is simply too easy.The main problem is that there just isn't enough intelligence in the script to stretch over the framework. Nice try. Not terribly bad, not terribly good.
summary: Justified is too simplistic to be good
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Thought  I would see just how  lame this show would be. Would I even watch an entire show? You saw those five stars. The dialogue alone is worth those stars. The characters? Yep they start out like some redneck cliches but they transcend into real people with surprising  layers.  When I saw that it had been inspired by Elmore Leonard it made perfect sense. Yes, it has a ridiculous amount of gratuitious violence and explosions....but it's the people that keep you coming back to this little meth hole in Kentucky. I couldn't leave them alone. A lot of stuff you just don't see coming , some of it subtle  some of it over the top. It's the subtle stuff you chew over....  ain't that right though?
summary: No turning back once you watch the pilot

reviewText: Cute, sexy main character - very clever and fast with a gun - BUT, as these "shoot-em-up-knock-em-down" things run, mediocre at best.  Story lines not believable - characters way to devoid of real human emotions, and way too good looking and well groomed for the way they live, sleep and eat - when will screen writers get it that if "art is to really imitate life," then they need to gain what any great writer has - VARIED LIFE EXPERIENCE - so that what they put on paper rings true to those of us living "real" lives.

reviewText: I was unaware of this show until the DVD came out and thought I'd give it a shot given the caliber of talent (both on screen and on the producer/writer level). Very enjoyable - the dialogue is smart and snappy, a combination that's become all too rare these days on TV. While everyone turns in a good performance, for me Walton Goggins is the star of the show. Fantastic performance - even better than his work on the Shield.Highly recommend, and can't wait for Season 2 on DVD!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Kinda like a cross between MacGyver, McCloud, and Crocodile Dundee (the US version!), Ryan Givens is a cool headed country boy turned lawman who drives a Lincoln Continental (shades of Frank Cannon!) and takes down the bad guys because offing them is “justified!” Lots of twists and turns, and often, if you’re watching on Amazon Prime, after one episode ends, you just have to check out the next one to see what happens next!

reviewText: I love westerns. Always have and always will.However, not all westerns are epic. Many westerns are cliched bore-fests and cover the same ol' tired trail-hand ground, story-wise, over and over again.Not so with JUSTIFIED:THE COMPLETE FIRST SEASON!An interesting and very addictive drama about a Deputy U.S. MARSHAL trying to clean up the Kentucky hometown that he doesn't ever want to be in! It's also got a great cast, some very slick writing, and cool action scenes! After watching the first season, I bought the second season right away!That's just how good it is!..Kind of makes me homesick for more seasons of HBO'S: DEADWOOD!...(wink! wink!)

reviewText: With the demise of "Firefly" and "Deadwood," where could we find witty scripts, believable action, and an interesting interplay between a home-boy lawman and his sketchy background? When Ben Folds sang about his "Redneck Past" it brought this series to mind.Please note that this series is not filmed in Lexington KY, although "set" there. There is a wonderful inside joke, possibly intentional or not, regarding the Tate's Creek Bridge: natives know that this has been a family-run ferry concession for years, so there is no Tate's Creek Bridge. A few issues such as setting some of these episodes in Versailles (pronounced just that way here) may raise some local hackles, since there are other communities a little better known for a less-polished contingent of citizens, but enough said.I recommend this to anyone who says they are not interested in "police shows," there have been several imaginative series like "Burn Notice" and "In Plain Sight" to show another side of law enforcement, but this is the real deal, as you would expect from the late great Elmore Leonard. Long may his spirit inhabit this production, when it goes, so will "Justified." If the show ever jumps the shark, the first season will still stand out as amazing.No point in naming individual cast members, all are uniformly superb, but I will name Walton Scoggins just because he was new to me, and now stands with Garret Dillahunt as the most creepy villain that you would still want to have a coffee with.Highly recommended to anyone who likes good dialogue and villains with many shades of bad.
summary: Just the best TV series in recent years
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I love this show on the FX network (thank God it is not a commercial, crap, network offering, but wish it was on HBO). This show is based on an Elmore Leonard short story, and Elmore was more than a little involved in the production of this series. Anyone familiar with Elmore knows dialogue is key, and there is plenty of clever scriptwriting to go around. The production people for the show write the bulk of the scripts, but they have a Leonard flavor to their works. The acting is great without being stereotypical of Southern folk. Dewey Crowe (played by Damon Herriman) is my favorite character (he was evicted from church camp for masterbating too much, an "onanist"). He's as dumb as they come, but Herriman plays it so well. Tim Olyphant, as Raylan Givens, is the quirkiest U.S. Marshall in modern day Kentucky. He's more lethal than a rattlesnake with a sidearm, yet quick to enjoy the pleasures of the flesh, and he is definitely not the sharpest knife in the drawer. Thank Heavens Olyphant doesn't play his role as Clint Eastwood, as he did in the HBO series "Deadwood" (one of the best Western TV series ever aired). This series has a definite Western movie feel to it. I miss a good Western, and this show has all the elements in spades. Walton Coggins does an exceptional job as Givens' adversary and sometimes friend. The women (Joelle Carter as Eva, Erica Tazel as Rachel Brooks, a U.S. Marshall, and Natalie ZEa as Raylan Givens' ex-wife) are all really pretty, and strong, and self-reliant. I wish season two would hurry up and finalize so I can get that one too. The 4 commentaries on the 3-disk set are fun and informative without being drawn out and dull. There are a few good "How we made Justified" documentaries, and a full video of the theme song -- a bluegrass rap tune called "Long Hard Times to Come" by the group Ganstagrass. Get it now!!!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Great show!!!  Well written.  The characters are developed throughout the year.  But I would definitely recommend starting with episode 1 and go from here.  I'm watching season 4 now and it all connects.  Each year there is a new major theme, but the character relationships continue from season 1. I would have hated to wait a week, or more, between episodes.  The series definitely holds your interest.  Before each show there is a short review of what happened before, but not necessarily what happened during the last episode.  The downside of the show is that it may make you want to start drinking Kentucky bourbon, starting at breakfast.
summary: Best TV I've seen in a long time.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: The series will get your attention and hold it throughout the season.  Characters grow and evolve as well as the relationships. reviewText: Justified:  The Complete First Season tells the story of going home, in this instance Western Kentucky area.  It does not matter where your "home" is, if you left it then it has changed greatly when you go back.  It is said that you cannot go home again, this series shows that it is true.  Deputy Marshall Givens is transfered back to his homeland after a shooting in Miami, and he arrives against his will to confront changes in people he grew up with.  This is really good TV, not what you expect from the people in Hollywood who love doing the same old thing time after time, with idiotic variations of a theme.  Based on a short story by Elmore Leanord, this series is worth having to view time and again.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I have to admit that I went into this series, not expecting much. When it went on to go into Season 4, I realized that maybe it was worth a watch.The first episode introduces us to US Deputy Marshall Raylan Givens, whom is sent off from a major US branch for a questionable dealing with a criminal to go work for a smaller, localized branch relative to his old home, Harlan County. The show does a good job of turning many episodes into routine assignments for the Marshall while maintaining the primary story of his coming to grips with a past riddled with questions and conflicts from a various cast of characters from a troublesome best friend, a critical and criminal father, an ex-wife who finds her own share of troubles coming to light, and some others.The writing is superb, the dialogue casual yet educated and witty yet subtle, and the stories are evolving.Usually, FX tends to invest good money into good series (Sons of Anarchy, Archer, Nip/Tuck, It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, and this) when they have enough of a fanbase to justify it. Fortunately, this show has become 'Justified' enough with its efforts to stand out.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Nothing deep or highly original about this show, which follows a US Marshal transferred back to his home state of Kentucky after a questionable shooting of a fugitive. But it sure is entertaining.  Based on or inspired by an Elmore Leonard short story, most episodes have that unique Elmore Leonard flavor--quirky hit men, dumb as wood henchmen.  Violent, funny, and (due to its handsome star) often sexy.

reviewText: Acting: most acting is top rate. I'm surprised to see other actors I've seen from movies appear in this show form time to time.Locational settings: interesting to focus on Kentucky area.Dialog:  refreshing and often funny and even intellectual.  It's nice to see that the locals are not generally portrayed as southern hicks with 2-digit IQs just because they speak with a drawl. There are dumb people everywhere.I liked Tim in 'Hitman' as well.  I love his charisma and swagger in this series.I liked to watch Walter Goggins in this series as well.  The character he plays is appealing: smart, cleaver, devious, mostly collected. He's definitely not a dumb country hick !The dialog between the lesser characters is also appealing.It gives me insight and depth into the story. It's not just about Raylon.Even the theme song is unique and catchy.
summary: This is an excellent show to watch after I finished Breaking Bad series

reviewText: We're big fans in this house!  A very different take on typical law enforcement dramas. reviewText: This is our favorite tv show. After four seasons, we decided to go back and watch reruns on Prime while we wait for the new season on FX. Since it's cable, the language is raunchier (without being overdone ad nauseum like in the movies). My mom never liked Timothy Olyphant before this show, but he is perfect as Marshall Raylan Givens. The rest of the cast is spot on too -- everyone from his boss, Art, to the just evil enough Boyd. The female leads are beautiful as well. my favorite is his ex-wife Wynona (Natalie Zea). The characters are the creation of Elmore Leonard, so the show's pedigree is excellent. This review is done for season one, but all four seasons are excellent.
summary: not just another generic cop show

reviewText: I decided to watch this show based on the TV Guide cover that called it one of the best dramas currently on TV. reviewText: I admit I never watched this show before, then did a glut of the whole first season.  I love it because of the regional relationships--law enforcement 'gets along' with criminals until they can't (jail guards who transport and watch prisoners often do this, and I've marveled at their ability to seemingly socialize with some very scary criminals).  My problem is with the Ava connection.  She's a conundrum because (if you listen) she's extraordinarily well spoken for a stay-at-home HS (only) grad, and has insights I wish we could see in everyone...but she's a total mess.  The premise that he regresses when 'back home' is iffy...but the shows and the threads connecting everyone, are great.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Justified is clearly in the top ten of current tv shows.  I expected a (typical) letdown in writing and/or acting in the second season, but it was just as good as the first season.  The acting is uniformly excellent by all concerned in every role. No signs of any self-consciousness from the actors that you sometimes get once a show gets recognized as a standout. I was a Walton Goggins fan from The Shield, and he is great here also.For Timothy Olyphant (or Justified) fans, I also recommend the movie "A Perfect Getaway" and,of course, Deadwood, First Season, in particular.  Deadwood lost a little in the second and third seasons, but the first season was also outstanding.

reviewText: I like "Justified" a lot, but I started watching during the second season.  I was delighted when Prime included the first season.  The first season, I find, is a lot more "Elmore Leonard-y" than the later ones.  The episodes are more self-contained; although there is also a season-long story arc it's not the only thing going on.  Most of the weekly plots are about crimes by not-exactly sane people. The bad guys, and sometimes the good guys too, get their eye so glued to the prize they lose all peripheral vision.  And there are a few laughs to be had before everything goes into the wood-chipper, as in many of Leonard's books.
summary: Best season for Elmore Leonard fans

reviewText: "Justified" (2010) was created by Graham Yost and is based on the Elmore Leonard novels "Pronto", and "Riding the Rap", and the short story "Fire in the Hole". Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) is a deputy U.S. Marshal who is sent to Lexington, Kentucky. Timothy Olyphant portrays a character similar to his character from the TV series "Deadwood", which was a 19th century-style lawman, but this series is set in the present day, and Raylan is the fastest draw in these parts. Raylan's hometown of Harlan is close to Lexington. Harlan is a rural mining town full of tattooed red necks, evangelists, and white suprematists. In other words, Raylan has his hands full. This is a well acted, dramatic, and clever show which also manages to be touching and funny.The blu-ray looks great and has a number of special features, including a look at the characters, story, with commentaries by cast and crew, and the music video "Long Hard Times to Come", which is performed by New York City based Gangstagrass.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I was hooked after the 2nd episode. Loved the characters, the romance, the humor.  Introduced me to a way of life I barely knew existed. Cutting back office deals.  The Law, cutting deals, or looking the other way, to accomplish a greater good.  Proved that some battles are more important to win. Some of these characters are like watching a train wreck. I can't fathom risking life and limb for money instead of working safe, respectable jobs!  Mind blowing!  I'm broken hearted at Raylan's childhood and his relationship with his father.  And it just gets worse.  But then, Raylan, wouldn't have turned out to be Raylan if not for his father. And Raylan is, after all, a good man.  Like the program so much, I'm watching it a 2nd time.  Raylan gets to do what probably law officials wish they could do with many of these punks.  And he is JUSTIFIED!!!
summary: First Episode drew me in. Second Episode clinched it

reviewText: I'm an avid TV series and movie watcher. I'm the type of guy who will buy multiple versions of one movie, and I'm the type of guy who will double, triple, or quadruple dip for a single movie if I like it enough. I like to think that I have a discerning eye for good TV. At the moment, I am only really hooked on 3 series. Mad Men, the Walking Dead (though that one is slowly waning) and Justified.Justified is without a doubt one of the most thrilling and entertaining shows I have EVER seen in my life. It's pitch perfect. Every single episode is worth watching time and time again. Timothy Olyphant throws it out of the park with his portrayal of Deputy US Marshal Raylan Givens. I could not quite explain why I liked his portrayal so much, but then it dawned on me that Raylan Givens is sort of like The Man With No Name in a modern setting. He is an old-school gunslinger in a modern world.The story-arch for this season is fantastic. Raylan Givens vs Boyd Crowder is damn fine television. I don't want to spoil anything, because it's just so fascinating. It's the type of series that hooks you from the first episode and doesn't let you go. You will watch multiple episodes in one sitting, and two season will not be enough.What are you waiting for? Buy this and enjoy!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: What is so engaging  about this TV series is the humor.  It's not a comedy, it's basically a twist on the solitary detective anti-hero, but it's the humor that sets this apart and makes it truly unique, the humor and the locale: Hazard, KY.  When are you going to see hollers and women so adept with shot guns and hear this lovely, courtly, almost old-English language?  Everyone is so polite to one another so that no one looses face as they take each other down.  This is not the boring old good vs evil.  We all know people are way more complex than that. There is a disparity in the accents.  There are a few too many scenes of conversations inside cars.  There is an unevenness in the female characters.  Overall, it's fun, it's engaging and it's a show that keeps me wanting to see what's next.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: If my friend had not told me about Justified I would have missed out on it. That would have been sad. Great  casting and acting, excellent writing, and the right amount of surprises keep a person glued to the screen. Since I was able to watch it on Amazon I was able to go from one episode to another without a break, which just added to the enjoyment. This series deserves to be given a similar place in television history next to the other great police shows such as Hill Street Blues and NYPD Blue. Although naturally exaggerated, this show brings a fairly fun portrait of the culture and personalities of some of the families trying to make it in their ancestral surroundings. And also exaggerated, but exciting, are the main U.S. Marshal characters as they carry on in the unusual environs in which they have been placed. So put altogether you have a show well worth the time you put into watching it.

reviewText: This isn't your average cop show. The star of the show, Timothy Olyphant, has created a character that is like no other I've seen before in the countless cop shows on TV. Olyphant plays Raylan Givens, a Deputy U.S. Marshal who was involved in a fatal shooting in his previous assignment which was deemed "justified". As a result he gets reassigned to the area where he grew up in Harlan County, Kentucky. He knows all of the local players and has a history with most of them. He has a personal style that I really enjoy. While I think that the investigations that he gets involved in is sometimes a bit over the top and not something that the U.S. Marshals Service would actually do in real life, I have no problem with it because it is well done and exciting. Each episode continues the storyline and keeps you wanting more. I can't wait for season 2 to be released.

reviewText: I've just begun my Christmas vacation from work, and based on previous good reviews, decided to check this show out. I've just completed watching season one. It is very well done, with brilliant acting and writing. While Timothy Olyphant is excellent, I actually find the most interesting character to be Boyd, played to perfection by Walton Goggins. The show is set in Kentucky, and being a Cincinnati native (on border of Ohio and Kentucky), and familiar with the area...it's also kind of cool to hear references to places I know so well. One would think, watching television/movies, that the majority of Americans either live in Chicago, New York or Los Angeles. It's nice to see the Midwest represented! :)

reviewText: Not my typical type of show but decided to try it anyway and was quite surprised. Justified is without doubt never a dull moment. Timothy Olyphant the lead of the series is remarkable in the portrayal of Marshal Raylan Gibens. The action is non stop including his personal life which is so entwined as to allow each episode to become more explosive. The portrayal of Harlan County's people is spot on as I have witnessed myself when traveling through the area years ago. The corruption and graft at least in the past is quite true and makes me glad to be far from the area. I am half way through season 2 and can testify that it only gets better.

reviewText: What happens when an East Kentucky boy leaves his home with no intention of coming back becomes a Deputy US Marshall and gets himself into trouble in Florida over a questionable shooting?  He gets reassigned to East Kentucky, and you have a great series-Justified.Raylan Givens, portrayed by Timothy Olyphant, brings a touch of the Old West to Eastern Kentucky. In the pilot episode-Fire In The Hole-you wonder if this young man is trigger happy or just plain angry or both?  His philosophy is-if the bad guy draws first, then the shooting is justified.Complicating his life is his ex-wife, Winona, who is a court reporter in Lexington, the home base of the marshal service. She's married to a land developer who is hiding something-this becomes a basis of a continual story line.An old friend, Boyd Crowder, is involved in some bad stuff.  Of course, the two old mining buddies face off and this becomes a continual sort of tension, especially when Crowder gets religion in prison and is released by the US Attorney because of Givens' involvement with Crowder's sister in law, Ava Crowder, who killed Boyd's brother at the kitchen table in the pilot.In essence this series so far in 13 episodes is about two sons and two old friends.  They have father issues, and their friendship is tested beyond measure for Boyd appears to be on the opposite end of the spectrum from Raylan.  Raylan is unconvinced of Boyd's religious conversion.The two old friends confront their fathers in different ways in the season finale-Bulletville. Raylan has to trust Boyd with more than his life as the final showdown takes place in one of the most spectacular gunfights that I have seen in series television.My favorite episode is Hatless.  Bulletville is almost equal as well.  For in Hatless you have Raylan facing his past and looking at himself in the mirror of yesterday.  Bulletville brings the previous 12 episodes to some climatic conclusions.The only major flaw is the location.  Eastern Kentucky is a beautiful place.  Shooting in Pennsylvania location scenes is not the same as Eastern Kentucky.  Let's hope in Season Two they travel down to Lexington and Harlan and shoot some scenes.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Love this show. One of the best on television. It is on FX, available on Netflix and for purchase on AMAZON.

reviewText: My fiance' and I started watching this series two or three weeks ago and are up to the end of Season 1.  Justified starts out strong and only gets better from there.  Timothy Olyphant embodies the lead character perfectly.  He has always seemed to be an odd fit as characters in films with his best being in The Perfect Getaway and I am Number Four and his worst in Hitman and Die Hard: This Has Gone for Entirely Too Long.  The failure of his character in the last two films was not on Olyphant as he is obviously a capable actor.  Hitman was poorly conceived start to finish and that Die Hard film was so stupidly over the top that his poorly developed character just came across as non-threatening.  Watch Justified and enjoy the banter between the characters and how polite everyone is even when they are diametrically opposed in life and motivation.  Its part of the charm of this series.  Everyone in the cast does a great job and the character of Boyd Crowder becomes particularly well realized with his unique brand of crazy.
summary: Timothy Olyphant is Brilliant in This
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I started watching Justified because I was bored with most live TV. The first season is pretty good - just enough explosions, good vs. bad, personal entanglements and humor to keep you watching. And while Timothy Olyphant is charming and wry as Marshal Raylan Givens, Walton Goggins as on-again, off-again bad guy and long-time Raylan Givens nemesis Boyd Crowder often carries the show away. The discourse between Raylan and Boyd is by turns witty, wistful, thought-provoking and sometimes just plain funny. The ensemble cast is pretty well defined and gets better through the season. Loved the season finale, too.That being said, currently watching Season 2 and have to say it's even better. Good watching!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Although not very true to life, this is a very entertaining series about a US marshal.  We follow his exploits from his original assignment in Miami to a reassignment in Kentucky, near where he grew up.  Our hero tends to run into trouble and adventure at every turn, but it is the dry sense of humor that prevails throughout every episode that really distinguishes the series.  This is a decidedly different and superior cop show. Highly recommended.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I absolutely love this show. Since I discovered this Prime Video, I promise myself that I will only watch one episode then retire for the evening. I've only seen the first 5 episodes, but Amazon asked me to rate it via email. If this improves, I'll update this review. For now, I think it's worth watching. reviewText: Justified is the story of deputy U.S. marshal Raylan Givens.  We quickly learn a couple major facts about Raylan in the pilot when he shoots a Miami cartel captain in a crowded restaurant and is subsequently re-assigned back to eastern Kentucky as punishment.  Raylan isn't afraid to use his gun, and he has serious issues with his hometown.  Justified is a modern western and more serial drama than procedural.The pilot is based on Elmore Leonard short story (Fire in the Hole) and it shows.  One of the greatest TV pilots I've ever seen, it's like an entire novel in 44 minutes.The title, Justified, refers to the justification for the various shootings Raylan is responsible for.  Raylan Givens is not a cop willing to step over any line for professional or personal reasons, a la Vic Mackey.  True to the title of the show, his shootings are always legally justified.  But while they keep to the letter of the law, they surely do not keep to its spirit.  In the very first scene of the series, the Miami cartel captain that Raylan shoots only pulls first because Raylan has promised to kill him and the deadline is seconds away.  Was it really justified to shoot a man after giving him 24 hours to leave town or die, even if he pulled first?  But Raylan IS a man with a code, explored most searchingly in The Hammer.  Raylan may make it look it, but his is not as easy road, as Rachel finds out in Long in the Tooth and Judge Mike "The Hammer" Reardan finds out in The Hammer.  Other major themes are family and Raylan's nihilism. The empathy he has for his adversaries serves him as well as his quick trigger finger.Justified is full of the witty dialogue for which Leonard is known.  Raylan, Boyd, and Ava are all wonderfully well drawn.  Raylan's co-workers Tim and Rachel suffer from a lack of attention, but are compelling to the extent possible given the limited attention they are given.  Raylan's boss Art, his ex-wife Winona, and her new husband Gary are all 3-dimensional minor characters.Like many drama series today, Justified attempts to balance between more traditional procedural episodes and episodes that directly tie into a larger, season-long narrative arc.  Much like Terriers, another underappreciated serial drama on FX, season one of Justified sets up the season-long arc in the pilot, pulls away from it for one-off episodes in rest of the first half of the season, then returns to it in the second half of the season, building to a season finale climax.  It comes off a bit clumsy everywhere I have seen it done, but Justified pulls it off well enough.The state of Kentucky is a character in Justified.  This is not a story that could have taken place anywhere but just happens to be set in Kentucky.  It is at its heart a story about Kentucky and specifically eastern, Appalachian, coal-mining Kentucky.  It could not have been set anywhere else.  The driving force of the show is not Raylan's conflicts with lawbreakers, but his inner conflict from being pulled in one direction by his family and his roots and another by his morals and his chosen life.Unlike most movies and TV shows, the southern accents sound right.  Perhaps it's not surprising, as Walton Goggins (Boyd Crowder) was raised in Georgia and Nick Searcy (Deputy Chief Nick Mullen) is from the mountains of North Carolina.DVD extras:  The commentary sometimes veers into Elmore Leonard-hero worship and mutual backslapping and inside, incomprehensible jokes, but it is nonetheless laden with golden nuggets of insight, in particular about the adaptation of the Leonard short story Fire in the Hole for the pilot.  DVD extras include commentary on Fire in the Hole, Blowback, Hatless, and Bulletville; What would Elmore do?; The story of Justified; Meet the characters of Justified; Shooting for Kentucky; The marshals; "Long Hard Times to Come" music video; Season 2: a look ahead; and previews from Justified season 2 (cut entirely from season 1 clips), Community, The Bridge on the River Kwai, and Red Hill.
summary: Serial Drama Set in Eastern Kentucky, Not Another NYC/LA Procedural Copycat
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This may be Elmore Leonard's first successful TV production, but it will for sure not get him an entry visa and a life time welcome in Kentucky.Our hero, a Kentucky boy working for the US Marshall Service, is transferred, much against his inclinations, to his home town area in Lexington, and gets entangled in all kinds of complications rooted in his previous life.His father is an aging gangster. One of his boyhood friends is a white supremacist and then, after a prison stint, a born again Christian with his own `church'. His ex wife, who had divorced him to get married to a realtor, is employed at court and continues to be an attraction and an enigma. A young woman, who had a crush on him as a young girl, still nurses her crush, but is on probation for manslaughter after shooting her abusive husband to death.Our hero is not immune to temptation, and he has a temper. He is also a good shot, and he scores one after the other, in good old Wild West ways. His killings are always `justified'. Anyway, the US Attorney's investigation into his shootings hangs over him like Damokles' sword.Violence is a favorite pastime in this Kentucky, among other entertainments. We have drug kitchens, pot growers, loan enforcers, armed robberies, hostage takers, racism, jail breakers, twisted cops, wife beaters, mass murderers, arms dealers... the whole nine yards. Jolly good fun.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This series has an interesting mix of characters, and I find it to be entertaining.  But you do have to suspend reality in order to watch it and enjoy the experience.  There is simply so much in the way of crime (in particular, murder) that is never investigated by authorities.  Some of the characters will simply kill anyone deemed to be in their way, and it is treated like a "normal" everyday thing.  Plenty of the lives taken will never become a problem for the perpetrators.
summary: Interesting, entertaining, but not near reality.

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: 'Justified' is a TV series about U.S. Marshall Raylan Givens, a character created by Elmore Leonard and is expanded from his short story 'Fire in the Hole!'. While the premise of the show seems by-the-numbers, it carries itself in a unique direction away from the usual crime series.After a shooting in Miami, Marshall Raylan Givens is reassigned to his hometown in Harlan County, Kentucky. The series progresses in an episodic manner as we learn more about Raylan's background and about the people he runs into on the job. These episode-to-episode plots may not sit well with some viewers accustomed to long story arcs, but the writers of this series keep things on an unpredictable level and I found each stand-alone episode engaging and watchable. It also helps that, though we do get some exposition on his co-workers the stories are (wisely)centered on Raylan himself. He's a great character to watch and the writers never forget that the show's about him.Speaking of the writing, the dialogue of this show is VERY sharp. There's still gun-fire aplenty in each episode (along with some well-staged shoot-outs) but it's the dialogue that moves the plot along. I really can't say that about any other crime show and that's REALLY what makes Justified stand apart from the rest.The dialogue of course wouldn't work as well as does if it didn't have terrific actors to deliver it. Timothy Olyphant proved in 'Deadwood' that he had the acting chops to carry his own show and he towers above all in 'Justified'. Equally good is Walton Goggins who (more-or-less) seems the show's chief antagnost. It's the crossroads that these two characters come to that electrifies this season's final episodes.This first season DVD comes with a decent amount of extras. The cast talking about their characters is nothing new to people who've been following this show online, but the commentaries (on select episodes) are pretty good with insights not only into the stories and characters (and the influence by Elmore Leonard) but the little details about the real U.S. Marshals.While Justified probably won't be everyone's taste I recommend everyone give it a try. With so many shows on networks recycling the same formula (from Soprano's or the Shield) it's nice to see a series like 'Justified' taking things in a slightly different direction. It's clever, funny, exciting, and unpredictable and will keep you wanting for the next season!

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This show has received a lot of effusive praise from those people who consider themselves a cut or two above the average t.v. viewer. "Justified" has some fine acting and very good production values. Nevertheless, the plot is contrived and bestows hero status on a lawman that supposedly grew up in the South, but comes across vividly as a typical northeastern character, dressed up superficially as a southerner. The main problem with the show is the obvious fact that the bad guys in the south would have killed the beafied marshal and ended is noble crusade against the fatuous people of the south. Timothy Olyphant is a problematic actor--in Deadwood he brought his character to life and was more or less convincing.  In Justified, he lacks the acting skills to transcend the flat character, created by the authors/producers of this show. Most of the time he has this confident, bordering on smug, look on his face that asks the viewer to consider him a really bad-ass who takes no guff from anyone. Although Walton Goggins, who plays the half-crazed villain (who likes to blow things up or start and watch fires) is excellent in his role, he still in essence is just another hillbilly hick that all discerning viewers should look down on. Also, it beggars belief to think that the marshal's ex-wife would marry such a milquetoast loser. All in all, Justified is entertaining, but lacks even a modicum of depth and complexity that make life authentic and interesting.
summary: Well-acted, high production values, but cheap shots at Southerners

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Any one who enjoyed "Deadwood" despite the plethora of obscenities throughout, will love "Justified" unconditionally. Tim Oliphant is back carrying a gun and using it repeatedly with "justification." His plain-spoken "He pulled first, I shot 'im" says it all. As Raylan Givens, Oliphant plays his modern-day U.S. Marshall simply, portraying a man who is not a hero but an uncomplicated law-enforcement officer who does not hesitate when faced by the many villans who "pull first" and are shot as a result. Oliphant is supported by a strong cast of individuals who are each distinctive and stand on their own. The writing is brief but clever, making use of the "one-liner" very effectively to convey meaning and mood. Many may condemn the violence on television, but "Justified" fills a person's need to know that bad people do not always avoid justice by getting lost in the justice system. When they make bad choices, like disregarding the firm command "Drop your weapon!", justice is quick, and its name is Raylan Givens. Call me blood-thirsty, but he's my Man.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: My only regret is that I did not tune in to this when it first aired. Timothy Olyphant personifies Raylan Givens perfectly. He's that rakish mix of cowboy (viz., the hat), modern lawman, bad boy, and (of course) good ole boy.

I tried to buy into it, but he just doesn't fit the bad-boy heroic cop image for me, and shooting his "old friend" just after arriving in his old haunts while they "chat" at the dinner table (similar to the opening scene) and just missing the heart did it for me, especially when his old friend has now had an epiphany upon waking in the hospital. I won't be watching anymore of this series. I just can't "justify" the waste of my time.

reviewText: Last spring I was eagerly anticipating the new FX series Justified starring Timothy Oliphant. (See blog post:[...] to read all about it.)If you followed my suggestion to watch this show when it debuted, then you know it's one of the best series to hit TV in a while.Inspired by the great Elmore Leonard, the series has topnotch writing. Good characters, interesting plots, great acting. Even an original bluegrass/gangsta rap blend for the soundtrack. Everything about this series makes it imminently watchable.I pre-ordered the DVD of Season 1, and it arrived on Jan. 18, the day it became available. My DH and I could hardly wait to view the entire season again. It's got some good Special Features. I especially love the music video of the theme music from Bluegrass Gangsta.Special FeaturesSeason Two: A Look AheadEpisode Commentaries: Fire in the Hole, What Would Elmore Do?, Blowback, Hatless, BulletvilleThe Story of JustifiedMeet the CharactersShooting for KentuckyThe Marshals"Long Hard Times to Come" Music VideoWhere are all the good movies? They're on TV disguised as series.

reviewText: Deputy U.S. Marshall Raylan Givens has been reassigned from Miami to his home town of Harlan, KY, after shooting a local drug lord & murderer after giving him 24 hours to "get out of town" or he would "shoot him on sight."  So, Raylan has no choice but to accept reassignment or lose his job and likely his career.  Upon returning to his "roots," Raylan must deal with the white supremacist Crowder family, one of whom - his cousin "Boyd" Crowder - he used to mine coal with.  Timothy Olyphant ("Raylan Givens") and Walton Goggins ("Boyd Crowder") are at odds with each other as they now are from opposite sides of the law.  While the first show filmed on location in SE Kentucky, subsequent episodes are quite obviously filmed in California, but unless you've been out there you'll likely not notice and it doesn't effect the storyline. If you've never seen he show before, it's definitely worth a look.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Gross violence just for the "fun" of it. Cheap, badly done imitation of Clint Eastwood. The violence, ridiculously implausible plots, shallow cardboard characters, the setting, even the weird unlikely music combo of redneck country/hip-hop, makes it clear that this tv show is obviously targeting uneducated, mindless, mouth breathing violence junkies. No one with half a brain, no person of any dignity or self-respect would even think about watching this manure of a show more than once.
