After only ONE Episode, I was hooked like heroine!!!  I now OWN the first 3 seasons, and we have so much fun now talking about the characters, that politics has taken a back seat to this topic, as well as DEXTER, which she also introduced me to.  I used to think she was WRONG about her views....  well, she's RIGHT about these programs and we have built on this foundation to have a much better relationship, now.  john

reviewText: I just love this series.  For one thing, the southern characters are actually believable rather than having those fake southern accents that make us all sound like a bunch of retardates.  For another thing, the stories are really cool and engaging.  The US Marshall who is the main character is very likeable and sexy and macho, but at the same time he has these vulnerabilities that make him human instead of some kind of comic book character.  And I guess lastly, the fact is that the episodes are kind of short, so you can fit them into even the busiest of schedules. reviewText: I tuned into Justified last March after reading a favorable critic's review just before it premiered on FX and have been hooked ever since.  It's my favorite show, best since Sopranos, and if you've never seen it do yourself a favor and give it a look.  The writing, some of which is based on the work of the great Elmore Leonard, is exceptional and the acting is topnotch.  Shining as bright as the lawman's star he wears is Timothy Olyphant, so perfect as Deputy U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens that after viewing a few episodes it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role.  Olyphant brings Givens to life as a heroic, yet very human character who's as likeable as they come.  He's surrounded by a great supporting cast, not the least of whom is Walton Goggins as Raylan's nemesis Boyd Crowder.  All thirteen episodes of the inaugural season are worth watching, with some being especially noteworthy.  The pilot is outstanding, introducing the players with the emphasis on Givens and exploring some of what makes him tick while also leaving some unanswered questions about this most interesting character.  Episode 4 is a personal favorite of mine, focusing on Raylan's pursuit of a fugitive and featuring a really neat desert showdown between our hero and a couple of hitmen.  Some of the episodes can stand on their own, while others are more serialized, but whatever your preference the more you watch the more you cannot wait to see what happens next.  Justified has drama and action, romance and laughs, and overall it's a real dandy of a show that is well worth watching.  I recommend it highly.
summary: A Real Dandy, Well Worth Watching
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Good cast that works well together, interesting writing involving real problems faced by real people.  Bit of stereotyping, but most shows do worse.

reviewText: Ok, a guy's guy (not to mention a girl's fantasy) makes a steely eyed challenge to an understatedly presented uber bad guy, that the bad guy's previously set time to give himself up lapses in ten more seconds, then out-draws him in a lightning quick flash, while sitting in a wind-blown outdoor restaurant in Miami, when the time lapses and the bad guy foolishly tries to beat him with a gun he shows above the table. Yes, fantasy-guy out-draws him. 2010.  Does it get better than that? Well, for the season, it stays pretty much like that. My wife and i enjoyed it, for somewhat different reasons...
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: ***UPDATE*** I gave Justified a second chance and I have to say that I like it more now than at first viewing. I was coming off watching some classic TV like The Wire and Sopranos, and I was probably too hard on this one. Changing Two Stars to Three and a half. A solid and fairly well done show that gets better (in my opinion) at the end of the first season.***My Original Review*** My favorite shows have big themes and go for big concepts: The Sopranos, The Wire, The Shield, Mad Men, Breaking Bad, Damages, Deadwood, even Dexter.I watched the first seven episodes of Justified and found it to be typical run-of-the-mill television fare with lot's of cliches, poor writing, complete lack of realism, stereotypical characters, etc. Olyphant is enjoyable to watch but if I'm going to watch TV I need better quality.Maybe I'm a TV snob. The first show seemed to be based on Elmore Leonard's short story and I liked it. But the writing took a nose dive after that first episode, and I quickly found myself wondering if the subsequent episodes were going to get better. In my opinion, they did not.I can't help feeling a show based in Kentucky or Appalachia could have gone the route of say, "Winters Bone", with colorful rural (but realistic) characters, themes of poverty, coal mining, isolation, etc. ***SPOILER ALERT***: When Olyphant stood his ground with a sawed off shotgun aimed at him at point blank range and walked up and snatched it away from the bad guy, I completely lost interest in the show. Utterly simpleminded and ridiculous writing without an ounce of credibility.The episode about the rich guy and the evil wife and the "Hitler" paintings...  cut me a break. ***SPOILER ALERT***: She marries the guy for his money and then kills him and plans to run away. That plotline was old when Columbo, the Rockford Files and Magnum P.I. were on the air.Too bad. There was potential for an interesting show here.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Very watchable. Main character is a US Marshal with great abs mad a killer smile. Pun intended. He is famous/infamous for outdrawing assorted criminals in shoot outs. He is an excellent Marshall who only shoots when it is.......justified, but his personal life is...you guessed it... A Mess. Our anti-hero is almost equally like-able but HIS moral compass swings wildly making him deliciously unpredictable. Other assorted yummiest include a straight-as-an-arrow local law enforcement officer, superb boss us older folks can identify with, smart and cruel ex/widow, creepily likable hog-dressing mafia boss, surprising well-drawn Yankee villain. Well, you get the idea. This is worth your time. Final moments of season three are FAB. My one quibble is that action takes place over an entire state and locations switch from scene to scene, so You mig get a bit of location whiplash, but hang tough, you gotta see the scene with the meat cleaver. One last thing, in case you haven't guessed, lotsa guns and gory at times. enjoy!

reviewText: I had been watching "Justified" as available on DirecTV and really got hooked.  The story line is unique and the characters are portrayed eerily realistic.  The main good guy and the main bad guy start out working together in an underground coal mine in the hills of Kentucky.  You get to know them both very well and even relate somewhat to the bad guy.  The show has some VERY violent scenes, but they fit seamlessly with the story line. The problem was that I kind of came in somewhere in the middle and had no control on what I was watching.  Then I signed up for Amazon Channel on ROKU and became really excited when I saw that I could watch every episode right from the Pilot forward and learn the characters and watch the whole story unfold.  Unfortunately this was going to cost me $2.99 per episode.  Then I discovered that I could watch it free if I joined Amazon Prime.  That decision quickly became a no-brainer since I buy quite a bit on Amazon.com and this would also give me free 2 day shipping on most of my purchases and I would no longer have to spend $25 for free shipping.  Since my goal is to replace DirecTV, which is costing me about $80/month, the $86 annual fee for Amazon Prime is cheap.  Not to even mention the tremendous amount of other programming.
summary: One of the Best Series On TV

reviewText: This series is based on a short story by Elmore Leonard ("Fire in the Hole"), in which he introduced the character of federal marshall Raylan Givens.It's well acted, often funny and has lots of little character and dialogue touches that are so reminiscent of Leonard. reviewText: "Justified" is an action packed, dramatic, adrenaline junkies dream, that will keep one on the edge of his/her seat anxiously waiting for the next episode.The story-line is always exciting, well developed, and never a boring episode that sometimes happens when the writers fail to produce anything but the best.Therefore, instead of fading, and becoming out right boring from lack of ideas...The writers are masterful while getting better with each season.In addition, the actors are convincing in their roles...never shy of the charismatic qualities necessary to achieve a spectacular performance!For example, Timothy Olyphant is magnificent in his role as U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens. A no nonsense, take no crap from anyone, fearless lawman who will do anything, including bend the rules to obtain Justice...Whereas the other actors are spectacular in their supporting roles helping this story remain powerful and exciting! Just an average TV Consumer, I have watched every episode with complete satisfaction!

reviewText: Timothy Olymphant is Deputy US Marshal Raylan Givens, a dedicated Marshall who is also a fast draw when he has to be. He is rotated back to take a duty posting in his home state of Kentucky -- a decision that he isn't right fond of, but soon discovers there is plenty of cleaning up to do in Kentucky that requires his own particular style.I've watched Season One from the Pilot all the way through the Season finale. I'll straight up say that "Justified" is quality TV entertainment. Take the modern adult oriented police procedural and combine it with a classic TV western, and there's your "Justified".The cast is strong, big time strong. Olymphant just rolls right along with the lead part, but he's surrounded by a supporting cast (and guest cast) that just immerse the viewer. Favorites include Nick Searcy as Art Mullen (Chief Deputy), a relatively easy going boss until you get him riled, and Raymond J. Barry (Arlo Givens), Raylan's father who has a big time checkered past and we as viewers still don't know it he'll ever be on the level with his son. I won't even get into the woman cast members, but suffice to say they *all* kick you know what and take big time names. "Aunt Helen" (who is now married to Arlo and played by Natalie Zea) is a tough, protective sort who brandishes a shot gun like every other episode and I'm surprised she hasn't hauled off and shot someone yet (and that one truck doesn't count, as she was at a distance.....)The show also has its own laid back humor, which is awesome. There is such as thing as a show taking itself too seriously, and thankfully "Justified" gives us the best of both worlds.The set Locations are a combination of modern housing, backwoods/country housing, and rough and tumble hill country - the viewer is immersed in the locations and the show through the characters as we are shown where they live.As for the Old West TV meets modern police show, three of the main cast members were trapped in a backwoods cabin while the "bad guys" peppered it with automatic weapons fire during the Season finale...How many time have we seen that scene in past westerns, and you can't get more Old West then that! As usual, "Justified" had it's own take on the situation, and that Rocks Out!If you like the police procedural, ensemble cast shows, or might want to check out a show centering on a modern US Marshals office in the Kentucky Hill territory, then I recommend the DVD set of the first season of "Justified".
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: "Justified" is that rarity in modern television.  Well written, intelligent, subtle (where plot is concerned), unpredictable with actors who do not seem to be in constant "pose" mode.Based on the work of Elmore Leonard, it definitely carries on Leonard's tradition of colorful and unpredictable characters while not getting so lost in "flavor" that the story suffers.  The production is very lucky indeed to have Timothy Olyphant on board, bringing a certain hard-to-describe low key charisma to his role, much as he did in "Deadwood".  In fact, his character in "Justified" has many similarities to his "Deadwood" ancestor - angry, gun-totin', does-not-suffer-fools and if-he-says-it-he-means-it.The supporting cast is equally up to the task (look closely for some "Deadwood" alumni).  The writing is great, but you have to have the talent to deliver it.  "Justified" does have the talent.  If you are in the market for a modern day western that throws off many of the tried and true modern day predictabilities, "Justified" is highly recommended.NOTE: If you buy the DVD set, BEWARE of the special features on disc 2.  A LUNKHEAD DUFUS producer gives away one of the key plot elements from the final episode.  How the folks who put together the DVD, and how a successful supposedly smart but ultimately LUNKHEAD DUFUS producer, could screw up this badly is beyond me.  So, if you buy the DVD set, watch the special features after you have seen the entire season.  Did I mention the producer is a LUNKHEAD DUFUS?
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I am binge-watching "Justified" on AmazonPrime b/c it didn't work in my schedule prior to this.  I am so glad I now have time to watch this very original series.  The character-development is superb!  I can't wait to watch each next episode!  I appreciate that the people of Kentucky are not made out to be stupid and in-bred (as they are so often stereotyped), although this is referenced.  The moral dilemmas of so many of the key characters make this show very relatable and authentic.  The relationships that "Raylan Givens" has with the people he grew up with, and now that he is a U.S. Marshall, makes the show complex, personal, even challenging at times.  If you have never heard of or watched this television series, I highly recommend starting from the beginning and going for it!!!  Timothy Olyphant is perfect for this role!!
summary: I can't get enough of this outstanding original series!!!

reviewText: Timothy Olyphant plays a U.S. Marshal in eastern Kentucky and has to juggle his career, his old friend who cannot determine if he is criminal or straight and narrow citizen, an ex-wife, and the community of thugs and other criminals in his home community. reviewText: Justified is one of my favorite television shows ever.  The writing is great, the casting is great, and it just works together to create great television.  You laugh, you cry, you can't wait to see more.  Great Acting by all of the cast -- LOVE the Raylan/Boyd relationship.  Two phenomenal actors.  The supporting cast is amazing too.  The way the lines are delivered just leaves you laughing and repeating the lines all week.  Writers -- you could not do a better job if you tried, please do not change anything.  -- If you haven't seen this show - you need to watch it.

reviewText: Some nitwit I work with has absconded with my Season One and I'm going to push him down in the flume if he doesn't return it soon.  This sets the tone for the whole series.  You just don't know what's coming next, but Raylan always warns you twice.  That one episode where Ferris Buehller's friend Cameron is a dentist and freaks out on a smart-ass patient and goes nuts and pulls his teeth out in a parking lot with a pair of pliers....well, it's just over the top.  It's like that all the time.

reviewText: This is fabulous TV, a show about really well-drawn, well-portrayed characters who are likeable enough that I want to keep watching them, even though most of them are criminals (which usually turns me right off). It's got violence and crime and poverty and lots of people on downward spirals (not all of them) -- all the things that usually have me reaching for the remote to go elsewhere. But I love these people! And the dialog is 100% priceless. Though if you watch too many episodes in a row, you may start talking like a hillbilly ...I was delighted to see this on Amazon streaming video, and delighted to start the series over by re-watching Season 1. (Really fun tip: Boyd Crowder wasn't supposed to survive the pilot, but he was just too good a character to lose.)
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Is anyone else bothered by the inanity of this episode? Too bad--I was starting to like this series.My gripe? You have a sheriff that needs to kill our hero. Simple. That's what he needs to do. What he REALLY needs to do (or the Miami bad guys will, ostensibly, kill him).Now...the hero does not know that the sheriff needs to kill him. Almost everyone in town still thinks this sheriff is a good guy. So what does the sheriff do? Turn on our hero when the two are alone--so the sheriff is in little danger of getting caught?NO! The sheriff burns every bridge in his life by kidnapping the damsel in distress in order to lure our hero to a location where...where...the sheriff finally addresses his need and kills our hero, right? Of course not! The sheriff has our hero DRIVE him to...to...oh...never mind...what difference does it make...This was one hell of a stupid episode.A big thanks to the show runner who thinks we are all idiots.Bravo!

reviewText: Seems like most reviewers love this show but being a huge fan of ALL FX series over the years I think this is missing something. It's not all bad but it certainly seems to fall short in some way. All season I kept waiting for it to explode like "The Shield" or like "Sons of Anarchy", FX's two best action series. I had watched the previews and waited with great anticipation for this series as the premise looked awesome. I adore Timothy Olyphant as an actor ever since he was the sherrif on "Dead Wood". He is something special and deserves a better written series. Being created by the same people as "The Shield" I expected it to be darker, grittier, action packed and filled with alot of suspense like the above mentioned show, but "Justified is a bit slow, like molasses on a cold day. It is interesting at times and I think has great potential, but I was disappointed with it. It never seems to go far enough. Each episode clears up a crime like a cheesy CSI spin-off. Toward the end things began picking up with the conflict escalating between he and Boyd and his family. I am not a fan of a weekly series of any kind that wraps up all loose ends, solves the case and puts the bad guy away all by the end of the hour. This show could be so much more and I will certainly give it another chance when it airs again. I like Sherrif Rayland and find him charming, funny and tough. As a viewer I have watched all of the other shows FX has created and know they can do better. Normally their series leave me on the edge of my seat and both my husband and I look forward to their programming, some of the best on television. "The Riches", "Nip Tuck", "Rescue Me", "Dirt", "Sons Of Anarchy" the new "Terriers" that kicks butt and of course the BEST cop drama of all time "The Shield". That is quite the line up of super quality shows and "Justified" needs a little punch to get it in the same category as these shows. All in all I hope the show does a bit better this season and expands in a couple of new directions. The acting is well done, really it is more of a storyline issue. Many nights I was ready to shut it off and go to bed, I kept waiting for that X factor that all hit shows need. I give it 3 stars.
summary: Not What I Had Hoped For Or Expected

reviewText: The show is slick but not too slick and a nice show. Raylan is a US Marshal sent back to his hometown in Kentucky because of a shooting in his last district. reviewText: Justified is a modern western set in Eastern Kentucky. Based on the works of Elmore Lenoard, its without a doubt the best written show I've seen in 2010. Timothy Olyphant plays the lead character. A modern US Marshall dealing with the lawlessness of a rural kentucky he thought he had left behind. Raylan also has to deal with his criminal father, friends he grew up with who went criminal, ex-wives and so on. The father does an especially good job. The plots often have twist endings which are well thought out. Olyphant plays his character perfectly.The only downside for me was that the final episode was too over the top. There was too much unrealistic violence and outright nonsense. It also kind of dug a hole in terms of where they can go next season. But the quality of nearly all the other episodes makes up for its flaws.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: While I didn't find this season to be up there with greats like Breaking Bad or Game of Thrones, I will say it's enough to get me to watch the second season. The writing does seem to be stuck on repeat at times, I mean how many times do we have to see Eva wielding a shotgun in one season already? But at the same time the links between characters and their at times unknown motivations makes for some interesting tv. It will be interesting to see if they're able to develop the writing and bring it to the level of it's peers on television or remains with the dial stuck at 8, so desperately wanting to hit 10 but not quite able.

reviewText: Great thing about TV episodes on Amazon Prime is I can watch four of 'em back-to-back, commercial-free and in sparkling High Definition and makes it feel like a miniseries or long form theatrical movie.Justified has an understated hero who's a quickdraw dead shot, and you know you want the bad guys to get what's coming to them. Like other FX series (The Shield), the dialog is peppered with spicy language you can't get on the broadcast networks, so it keeps your attention and makes you want to watch. I hope to be caught up with this fine series by the time the 5th season premieres on FX January 10th. Your time watching this show will definitely be Justified.

reviewText: This is a wonderful new show about an old west style Marshall in a new style world, and all influenced by Elmore Leonard. The dialogue between characters is great for those who love language. The plots for stand alones are good, and help flesh out the characters for the later episodes that are part of a multi-episode arc. The final half of the season is just great, as all the strands are pulled together, and friends become enemies, enemies become allies, and we get to see one of televisions all time great dysfunctional families in the Givens.This is a show for thinkers and lovers of the little things that make all the difference. It has excellent acting and a constant wry sense of humor.

reviewText: It's gritty and has some bad language but this show shines on it's writing and acting.  Tim Olyphant is the best TV lawman ever and Walter Goggins could carry a show all by himself. The rest of the ensemble cast is similarly talented and the writing is spot-on.  Having grown up in the South I don't just relate to some of these characters I KNOW them (or at leat their real-life counterparts).  Congratulations also for most of the actors actually getting the Southern accent correct (especially Walter Goggins who is from AL and grew up in GA).  "Arlo's" fake accent sounds like a cheesy "Gone With The Wind" imitation but most everybody else is either genuine or does a fine job of imitating.
summary: One of the best-written, well-acted shows on TV

reviewText: I really enjoy this modern western! And that's what it is. Tim O. is great as the lead character a straight laced marshall whose dad is a major criminal. the whole rual kentucky area is done well too. And these days with drugs destroying whole states and countries , rural areas are even more violent than they ever were. The dvd set is inferior to the blu ray set in many ways. The blu ray looks great , the dvd set is smeary in places.  The first season introduces the main characters among who the most intriguing is of course Boyd Crowder, he's a man with a huge intellect and he's driven by first racism and then relgion in this series. But he does change as the show enters it's second series. But he is a man who if he hadn't grown up with a local crime boss as a dad might have been a college professor. The actor who plays him deserves a emmy imo. This is a western show set in todays lawless america and lets face it , today it's really bad crime wise, with even the rural areas overrun by crime and drugs these days.
summary: excellent show. get the blu ray version.

reviewText: I mainly watch movies and I tend not to watch TV shows, the low budgets and the pressure to churn out episodes on a weekly basis make them pretty weak in my mind, but this is a very good TV series.  I like it mainly due to Timothly Olyphant, who I think is a great actor, but the show is very good also, especially the opening sequence with the Miami gunfight.  How original!  And the event isn't forgotten about and never mentioned, as so many TV shows do, acting like everything that has come before it never happened -- it constantly comes back to affect situations, just like real life.  The DVD has good extras and background on the show, which also makes it a good buy.  The show probably won't get any better than this first season, since TV series tend to milk their ideas pretty quickly then run out of them, so get this and enjoy it, especially if you, like our family, can't get enough of Timothy.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Exciting stories and realistic violence. Raylan is flawed but heroic. A look at small town America in hard times. The good guys win eventually.

reviewText: I've been a Timothy Olyphant fan since his Deadwood days. He does not disappoint in Justified. It's a quirky show filled with quirky characters about whom I have come to care. There is more gunplay than I care for but it fits the storylines, so I suppose I shoulldn't complain. The stories are well-written and the situations are often surprising. I found myself watching multiple episodes at one sitting. The first season would rate five stars except subsequent seasons are even better.

reviewText: I started watching this show midway through the second season because of Timothy Olyphant (of Hitman and Deadwood) but here he shines! I went back and purchased the first season. I love the back and forth between him and his childhood friend Boyd. The show does demonstrate both the negative and positive 'types' of Sourthern folk (of which I have proud Southern roots).  The show writers and actors capture the essentials of the southern small community - you know all your friends and neighbors and outsiders are usually are not welcommed.  Really one of the best written and acted shows on TV. I wish it got more recognition.  For me it was a must buy and I recommended it to all my family and friends. :-). The quest stars seem to have really good roles as opossed to just popping in to boost ratings.  Kristen Bauer was great! That was a role she could sink her teeth in!  The female leads in the show are fantastic.  I could go on and on, but do yourself a favor and watch.  You won't regret it.

reviewText: This show has the best dialogue ever. I started watching Justivied because it is set in Kentucky. I was born in Harlan and lived there till I was 8. Went back every summer to visit relatives till I was 18. Never saw anyone there with bright white capped teeth like Boyd Crowder has. Never heard anyone talk like him either.Also, it's about a 2.5 hour drive from Lexington to Harlan, and these characters pop back and forth at the drop of a hat. Not logical, but I guess all shows take such liberties.If not for the "over the top" violence (90% of it unnecessary), I'd give the show 5 stars. The dialogue, especially that of Raylan Givens is top notch.

reviewText: Timothy Olyphant is back in his cowboy role as a gun slinging U.S. Marshall with borderline anger issues.  Something of a toned down version of his character from DEADWOOD.  The spin on this series is that the main character is working in his Kentucky hometown and a lot of the people he knows are criminals, including his father and one of his old mining comrades.  Southern KY sensibilities are done particularly well, especially the racism and their pro gun sentiments.  This TV series was based on some novels and a short story by Elmore Leonard.  CHARACTER/DIALOGUE: B; STORY/PLOT POINTS: B; SOUTHERN FOCUSES: B plus; OVERALL GRADE: B; WHEN WATCHED: April 2011.

reviewText: I cant imagine a more perfect actor to play the main character of Justified than Tim Olyphant. He was great in Deadwood and his cool style and good looks make for a wonderful 21 Century US Marshall forced to return to his past and his home of Eastern Kentucky, dealing with old friends turned bad, facing small town living and his ex-loves. The supporting cast is also very talented and the story lines are fresh and varied. Every episode explores new ground in characters and plots. The serious problems confronting rural communities such as drugs, poverty, and police corruption are handled with skill and insight.

reviewText: Being a fan of HBO's Deadwood and liking Timothy Olyphant in the role of Seth Bullock, I tuned into Justified the first night it aired on FX. This is the role he was born to play. As Marshal Raylan Givens he kills one bad guy too many (or too quickly), then gets sent to the backwoods of Kentucky where he grew up to lay down the law his own way. There he encounters an old crush, his ex wife, his criminal father, his childhood friend who has become a racist and murderer, played wonderfully by Walter Goggins, and a whole slew of memorable weirdos. The show has just the right amount of gritty violence and occasional humor to go along with the sometimes overly simple and often familiar storylines, but even that can't take away from the coolness and charm Olyphant injects into this shoot first, ask questions later cowboy. Definitely one of my favorite new shows.
summary: A man made for the Wild West, just born over a century too late
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Just to let you know, I am not a fan of weekly shows on television. Everytime you get to watching a show, it disappears. Got hooked on Human Target on blu-ray and started watching it on tv, yet Fox keeps movingit around to variable nights and times where I just quit watching it (I'll wait for season two blu-ray).Back to Justified. This is an amazing transfer on blu-ray for a television show! Never cared much for Fox and its affiliates (like FX) because they broadcast in low-res 720p. Got this blu-ray under 20 bucks (great price for a whole season!) and was really captivated by the clarity and detail of the image! No grain, no dirt, full of bright colors. It is hard to believe a television show can look this good! I am sure it has to do with the resolution now being 1080p, instead of 720p. Glad I didn't settle for the DVD instead (was thinking, its tv...how good can it look?) and boy, did I make a good choice! Spend the extra few bucks to get this blu-ray. Besides, the shows pretty good, too!! Looks like I will be watching season two (even though its only 720p...I'm hooked on this show!).
summary: For television, this blu-ray is a sight for sore eyes! This is an outstanding blu-ray!

reviewText: The setting is modern times, but is as fleshed out as a period piece.The characters are detailed and fascinating -- even the bad guys/girls.This is a crime show, obviously, but the crimes fall between Organized Crime and Wild West...some slow to develop and some frighteningly quick and brutal.This show is GRITTY!We love it...there's never a moment when you want to turn away.

reviewText: Well put together show.  A slightly off beat U.S. Marshall who should have been born 100 years earlier.  He is a gun slinger.  His shooting of criminals are justified.  First episode he told a scumbag he had to be out of town by noon or he was dead. At noon off beat Marshall meets with scumbag who pulls a gun on the Marshall who shoots him in a quick draw.  The killing was Justified, thus the shows name. Gets better in the second episode where he kills the husband of his soon to be girlfriend.  Again it was a justifiable shooting. Good show lots of action.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Justified is the latest offering from FX.  It's based on a short story by Elmore Leonard, and is worthy of that association.  Timothy Olyphant is pitch-perfect as Raylan Givens, a modern gunslinger who's the hero of this story, but also a flawed man.  Olyphant can "wear a hat and shoot a gun" (creator Graham Yost's words), but the rest of the cast is great.  Walton Goggins is so good as Boyd Crowder that his character got a reprieve (he was supposed to die at the end of the pilot), and actors like MC Gainey (Bo Crowder), Raymond J. Barry (Arlo Givens), Joelle Carter (Ava Crowder), and Jacob Pitts (Tim Gutterson) are splendid.  Special mention must be made of Nick Searcy as Chief Deputy Art Mullen.  He's so perfect it seems as though this role has just been waiting around for him to find it.  Add in special guest stars like Stephen Root, William Ragsdale, Alan Ruck (in "Long in the Tooth," one of the best episodes), and especially Jere Burns as one of the creepiest bad guys around, and the acting is obviously in good hands.The writing is sharp and observant.  The show taps into one of the funniest facets of Leonard's writings, namely that most criminals really aren't very smart.  Dry humor and tart dialogue abound.  Like all great crime dramas, everyone has a motivation.  Even the worst characters have personalities with wants and desires that direct them rather than the writer's whim.  The incorporation of the Dixie Mafia and the redneck drug empires that exist in out-of-the-way hollows of lower/working class America give Justified a grit and pace that have a different feel than most LA/New York based cop show/procedurals.This is a tremendous show, revolving around a character summed up by Chief Deputy Mullen (in season 2):  "Raylan, you're a terrible Marshal and a good lawman."
summary: Rip-roaring action and great characters to boot
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Loving this show! Although I was born and raised in small town Texas, I think I may have gone to school with guys like this and many of the characters depicted in the series.  It's addicting!  Too funny and too true to life in small rural southern towns.  I am so smitten with the series I had to identify the author who originated the story-line and found he has many audible books, another passion of mine, available through Audible.com and will be spending some credits to check them out.  At least three of those books feature the Rayland Gavin character as the hero.  Looking forward to this month's credits so I can download the first audio book.  If you grew up in rural southern America, I highly recommend this series, just be prepared to be immersed in hometown nostalgia.  There's a reason why they say "you can never go back"... Enjoy!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This is the first time I have seen this series and it is very good.  Love the southern accents since it is in Kentucky.  It is still on TV at the time but I don't have cable so via Amazon is how I have viewed and enjoyed it.  Hopefully it will stay on for many seasons to come. reviewText: Just a fantastic show. Elmore Leonard said that Timothy Olyphant was exactly the right choice for the way he imagined the character when writing the books. I'm not surprised, he's great. So is the rest of the show, and you should watch it.

reviewText: This is a show that not only do I enjoy but my spouse enjoys as well.  I am from Kentucky and grew up in the area that this show is based upon.  Too bad they do not film the show in the area.  The area they use is similar but not nearly enough mountains.  I understand it is cheaper but they could at least get some shots that they could use in every episode.  I like that the accents are not over done and that they have used several actors that are originally from the general area and therefore do not have to use those fake over exaggerated accents that so many shows use.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This is a show for the intellectual who wants to relax and have his intellect stimulated at the same time.I'm so sorry I missed this series when it aired originally but am very grateful to Amazon for making it available again.  I love the humor and clever use of the English language.  Tremendous writers.  The dry humor of "Raylan" and "Bo Crowder" keep me in stitches.

reviewerName: Neo, the renaissance man "s/w designer in a h...
reviewText: I prefer more comedies, maybe even dramadies, sometimes.  And of course the mainstream criminal shows, especially some of the ones related to the US Navy (I'm sure you an guess).  But, this one is strangely compelling.  It's definitely one of the more, if not most, violent shows I've watched.  And, it's got its fair share of the "I can't believe people actually do that" soap segments.All in all, I'd recommend it.  With a strong proviso - NOT FOR THE FAINTHEARTED and NOT for kids.  Probably not for kids under 17 even with both parents.  I know, lots of kids experience more than this in their video games.  But that's another story.  Maybe they could grow up more slowly and avoid this kind of experience until they're more able to develop rational thought on their own.This show does glorify extreme violence.  But it's definitely part of the story - and a well written, well scripted one.  And, it's definitely part of real life - just maybe not so much in one place at a time.Oh, and the acting is really well done.  There's a heckuva a good team in this series, and they started right in like they'd all been working together for a long time.
summary: I wouldn't normally have watched it, but I like Tim Olyphant and decided to give it a try

reviewText: Overall a VERY enjoyable show about a modern day MARSHALL in Kentucky. The lead character is handsome and smart and interesting to watch - good writing, good acting, fun, sexy, charismatic, smart.It's a show that's meant to be watched in order because it's an ongoing story - not just a new criminal hunt each week. reviewText: This series was so good in every respect.  The actors don't "mumble", Walton Groggins is amazing - clear even when whispering!  It has humor, suspense, realisim, and the music doesn't drown out the melodrama.  I'm already up to Season 3 and look forward to watching it every time.  I was so impressed with the Boyd character, I had to go and look up who it was online.  Not until the 3rd season did his name appear prominently at the beginning of each episode.  Watch it - you'll have hours of entertainment.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This review is written having seen seasons 1-3, and the first 2 episodes of season 4.The first season of Justified is a good start to an excellent show.  The series found its identity toward the second half of season one.  Initially, the show is more episodic - episodes are relatively self-contained, with the "villain of the week" getting their just desserts at the end of the hour.  There is growth in the overall story, but it's doled out slowly - think of a show like "Bones", where the overall plot is inched forward veeery slowly.  Seasons 2 and 3 (and what I've seen of 4) have a larger, season-long story arc that's more akin to a show like "Damages".By the second half of this season, the show found its footing, with a longer plot arc, and turned Boyd Crowder, initially a one-off villain, into a recurring character who's central to the show.This is still REALLY good TV, but the first few episodes are more "cop drama" than what Justified turns into in later seasons.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: We are enjoying Justified.  The characters are interesting andenough story line to keep you intrigued.  Hopefully, it will remainso for the entire series, which goes on several seasons.

I learn not to get to attached to anyone because they will probably get killed in a most violent fashion before long! LOL

reviewText: A delightful blend of humor and action, "Justified" follows Deputy Marshal Raylan Givens in his attempt to find justice without tripping over the red tape of modern criminal justice procedure. He imports old West values and uncomplicated methods into the modern South with disregard for every rule and regulation with stands between him and the villains he pursues, or who as often pursue him. He has a tendancy to shoot these aforemention villains after maneuvering them into "justifying" his use of deadly force. ("He drew first.")The acting is excellent, with a season arc antagonist played to over-the-top perfection by Walton Goggins, and a supporting cast apparently having as good a time as we viewers. Although there is a familiarity with the lone warrior of justice against a sea of bureaucrats (going back at least to Toshiro Mifune in "Yojimbo"), "Justified" brings an adrenalin burst of fresh humor and perspective to the genre.
summary: No red tape for Marshall Givens
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Having loved Timothy Olyphant in Deadwood, I decided to see what he had been up to since Deadwood was canceled. I was delighted to find a first-class crime drama where the interaction of the fully-drawn cahracters is as much fun and as riveting as the shooting up the Kentucky countryside scenes. Every time I decide to really dislike someone in this fast-paced show, I am shown a scene that touches me and makes me questions my emotional choices. The other fun part of this show is the incredible amount of humor that is dispersed throughout. If you like westerns, police procedurals straight-up dramas or action flicks, this show is for you. I can't reccomend it any stronger than that. It is one of my all-time favorite shows of all time.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This is a pleasing western format in a modern setting, authentically done for the Appalachian setting.  It takes the home culture of the star seriously, and the details of the surroundings, the accents, the rich characters all make for what seems like an authentic representation of the situation.  They take seriously the changes someone from rural Kentucky might go through working in "foreign" urban cultures of the US, in a federal law enforcement role.The main character is faced with his own personal cultural challenges when reassigned back to his home areas, much changed from the earlier period of his life when he lived there.  The crimes and related undercurrents in local society are interesting and engaging.

reviewText: Justified - Season 1 - [2014-01-31 500]Summary:Raylan Givens, U.S. Marshal has a problem. He's a trouble magnet, which result in bodies being piled up much to the consternation of his superiors. After a shootout in Miami - where a drug kingpin was killed - he is sent to Kentucky near Harlan County - noted for it's crime families, drugs, moonshine and, not incidentally deep family associations with Marshall Givens.Content:The Season One package consists of 3 disks and 13 episodes originally shown on the FX network starting March 16, 2010. Also included are several special features on disk 3 that I founding very interesting and added to my enjoyment and understanding of what the creative types wished to accomplish. Unfortunately there was no "special feature" on Elmore Leonard the real genius behind the series.Positive Comments:This is a fascinating show with an excellent cast of well-developed characters. I was never bored and except for a few random occasions felt that the narrative was logical and reasonably believable.The Cast:The two main male leads are exceptional. Timothy Olyphant as Marshal Raylan Givens brings a sexy swagger to the role of a self-assured lawman that must contend with his dysfunctional family and community. Walton Goggins as Boyd Crowder is mesmerizing as the man who miraculously returned from apparent death with a shot to the chest courtesy of Marshal Givens. Boyd has morphed into a charismatic mystic with a hatred for drug dealers.Negative Comments: No deleted or extended scenes. Sometimes these are almost as enjoyable as the episode - and I'm next too positive they exist - but not even one was included in the season 1 boxed set! The female interest appears to be motivated by their hormones rather than their intellect. Both ladies just can't hold back from jumping in the sack with Raylan much to his determent. Yes a moment's pleasure but a full bucket of woe! Don't ever think of missing a week of this show since the season's story unfolds from episode to episode. Characters pop up from two or three shows ago and plot threads are pulled and expanded from several episodes back. This is not necessarily a negative unless you have no intention of ponying up for the full season set or won't watch it on pay per view. In that case you will have a difficult time following all the story lines..  Residents of Kentucky may find this series objectionable.Recommendations:This is a high-energy show with a penchant for violence, raunchy sex and lots of very bad dudes. Just so you know in case you object. I found it quite entertaining and would like to see Season 2.
summary: The Old West in modern Kentucky works for this viewer
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Well written series... Often predictable - but much like Clint Eastwood movies - you know what to expect and you watch with the anticipation your expectations will be fulfilled. This is just plain fun cops and robbers stuff that you can watch and enjoy.

reviewText: This is a really great new show. It has a unique twist on mystery/crime, they built the characters right from the first episode and made even the worst of them slightly likeable.  So many shows these days have no likeable characters, even the "good guys" are jerks - not flawed like regular people, but absolute jerks.  This show found a a way to make the "good guys" be flawed but good-hearted, and the bad guys less unlikeable - but bad guys.  The story lines are interesting, setting is unique, and it's funny in subtle ways that make the hour fly by.

reviewText: I had been noticing Justified for some weeks and finally decided to try it. Was I ever missing one of the best TV stories I had ever seen (including movies). Once I started watching I could hardly stop. I watched all three series in just a few days and now can't wait for more. Timothy Olyphant is perfect for the part plus the other characters in the story. Very well written, I did not notice any parts of the series that I did not enjoy. I would highly recommend to any adult looking for something to thoroughly enjoy. Once one starts I bet it will be hard waiting to see the next episode.

reviewText: Raylen Givens is a classic anti-hero. He's one of the good guys, but not entirely good - he has his own ways. They've borrowed a few moves from Bogart, in fact, such as making an entrance by delivering a thug back to his master (Duffy), just as Bogart did in the Maltese Falcon. But Timothy Olyphant is an excellent actor, and carries off the part perfectly. It's a joy to watch him and Walton Coggins work a scene together.My only complaint about the series is that it paints an unfair picture of Eastern Kentucky. Having grown up in Kentucky, I can say that most people there are honest, intelligent, and reasonable people. There are a few idiots in the hills, to be sure. Take the senator from Eastern Kentucky; please! But most folks are bright, hard-working, and not of the criminal class. They don't make very interesting characters of course, and so the plots are exaggerated, and the result is excellent drama.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I became a fan of the current season on tv, so going back and watching how it all got started has been just great . It's amazing how he's always been just such a badass it's just great . reviewText: My husband got me on this show and now, I am hooked!  I am not really familiar with the actors on it but they are very good at their craft.  We just finished the first season and will start on the second.  The lead character, like all the characters on the show will rope you in to the drama immediately.  What I like about the show is these characters are not black and white, but gray, flawed and struggle with their values and therefore are human.  Raylan is handsome, a crack shot, but struggles to do his best and use his wits to avoid using his gun.  He is a federal Marshall and you will love this character.  I know this show did not need another five star review, but I love the story and can't help but being fond of those shotgun toting women in Raylan's life. You will love it!
summary: This show Justified is justifiably addictive!

reviewText: I have to confess that I was not that impressed by JUSTIFIED at the beginning.  The first few episodes were good, but it did not at the out start have a compelling long term arc, or rather didn't obviously have one.  I simply won't watch shows that don't tell an overarching story over the course of the series.  Nothing makes me lose interest in a show more quickly than a succession of stand alone episodes, which is one reason that I have virtually no interest in pre-1990 television (with rare exceptions, like THE PRISONER and TINKER TAILOR SOLDIER SPY and THE TWILIGHT ZONE and MONTY PYTHON).  But with the gradual development of long story arc television in the eighties, TV transformed from a media that I had virtually no interest in to one that I prefer strongly over the movies (and this from someone who ran a couple of film societies in grad school).So, my fear was that JUSTIFIED was going to be a series of standalones.  But luckily, it developed a great ongoing storyline with a surprisingly likable cast.The writing for the show wasn't quite as sharp as for shows like THE SHIELD and THE WIRE, but it was strong by the standard of most shows, and the cast was exceptional.  I had always wanted to see Timothy Olyphant in another story after the prematurely cancelled DEADWOOD, in which his extraordinary performance was sometimes overlooked by a host of equally strong characters.  Here Olyphant comes into his own and his portrayal of Raylan Givens made him perhaps the most enjoyable lawman on television at the moment.  Wayne Goggins proved in THE SHIELD that he was one of the best actors on television and he proves it again here in this one as an exceptionally complex southern redneck who is in turn a white supremacist, criminal, drug dealer, religious zealot, and reformer.  Even at the end of the season it is hard to classify him as a good or bad guy.  A lesser actor might not be able to pull it off, but Goggins nails it.My recommendation for anyone who tries this but isn't immediately delighted with it:  give it a chance.  It will definitely repay your interest and I'm sure that most viewers will enjoy Raylan Givens as much as I do.
summary: Completely won me over by the end of the season
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this series.There were a few early weaker episodes and then it got serious...better and I looked forward to this somewhat quirky series. reviewText: I stumbled across Season 1 of Justified while cruising Amazon Prime and I'm glad I did; this series has got to be one of the most interesting and captivating series to come along in a long time; the characters are interesting and the plots are well-written.  I just completed viewing Season 3 and can't wait for Season 4.  This series is not for Opera types; it is a hard hitting story about a deputy marshall in a backwater town in Kentucky; but the characters are so 'real life'.  This series is like a good book that you just can't stop reading.  Try Season 1 and just like me, you'll stay up until midnight every night until you complete Season 3.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I only caught two episodes while this season aired, but sure wanted to see more. I bought both the first and second seasons on Amazon at a good price, and glad I did. The series did not disappoint me!The Sony Blu-Ray discs are a pain in the posterior to play, apparently only made for compatibility with Sony's Playstation 3. Since I don't play video games, I don't own one; I watch movies on my laptop using Cyberlink PowerDVD 10, which has a work-around. Unfortunately, the work-around still doesn't make up for a complete lack of menus, so there is no access at all to special features. I'll look more closely in future for publisher information, to avoid Sony products.

reviewText: So far after only watching the pilot for this FX Network series I can honestly say we have yet another cookie cutter show! How can I say such a thing you might ask? Well lets start with the basics like the formula for the lead character Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) U.S. Marshal. Is he a rogue lawman? Yes. Does he have at least one parent who's a criminal? Yes, his father. Does he have anger issues? Yes. Does he have other baggage? Yes he does. Does he dress like fellow marshals? No, he has his own uniform style including being unshaven. Does he carry a regulation firearm? No, he uses a multitude of weapons. Whats his trademark? He is a throwback to the 1800's when someone draws down first and you kill/wound them "Its Justified" Can he get the ladies? Why yes he can. Is he always in trouble with his boss and the DOJ? Yes he is. Is he the one person they have to call upon to get the job done? Yes he is. The acting, locations and direction all seem to rate in the good range and the writing from the pilot appeared to land in the middle of the pack range for TV programs. Was it a waste of time to watch? No, but the worn formula is the same as so many others that came before it and most likely after it too. Is it entertaining? Mildly. 3 StarsRating 0 to 5 StarsStory = 3 Pretty standard material and characters here.Acting = 3+Direction = 3+Action = 3 Gun play and an explosion.Violence = 2+ Gun stock hits to the head and a elbow or two.Foul Language = 1 Light and not as much as many others.Gets much worse with each episode. 4+Entertainment Value = 3 Its not bad, but its based on a tired and overused formula. If everything else is a rerun then watch this until new programing restarts.Ps. I will continue to watch this show from time to time when time allows to see how it and its characters evolve with each passing season.Ps. Part II I have watched the first four seasons now and have somewhat changed my opinion on the show. The character development is good and will give an idea of the mindset between the main characters and their relationships/interactions with one anotherThe acting is good for the most part with a few exceptions from the secondary characters. The dialogue seems fitting for the region, but can get a little on the foul side from time to time and the stories are entertaining although they tend to be very predictable. There is plenty of violence to satisfy diehard fans and the occasional partial rear view nudity shots of male and female characters. I do enjoy watching the show if I can't find something else that I would rather of watched and spent my time on.The shows standard well worn formula and its predictability is what hurts the shows performance and shoots itself in the foot keeping it from being a runaway hit. I know that I'm in the minority with my 3 star review, but it just lacks any kind of originality and is way to predictable and not thought provoking enough! Still it's worth the time if your bored and run out of first run movies or TV shows.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Compelling stories.  I hope the violence and poverty are exaggerated, unfortunately it is probably close to the truth.  I was hooked on Downton Abbey and then Justified, it may be difficult to switch back from the hollers of Kentucky to the  mansions of Downton Abbey.

reviewText: This is a series, I hadn't really even heard about, and just came across on Amazon Prime videos.  It is so cleverly written, and witty, I am surprised it is under rated.  The characters, are  well played, there is a slow build up of the relationships of the ensemble cast, and story line.  We love the dialogue especially. Clever, witty, and quirky. It probably helps our view of it, that we are from the south, since it is set in Kentucky.  We love Raylan, and Boyd.  Just a really good series, I am sorry season four isn't on prime yet, but maybe it will be soon.  We have to stop watching three episodes a night, to make it last a little longer.  If you like crime drama, with witty dialogue, plot settings, and likeable characters, this is one you should watch.  We love it.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I became familiar with Deputy US Marshall Raylan Givens from reading Elmore Leonard's novels Pronto and Riding The Rap and am finally finding out that he is the main character in FX's series Justified.The series itself is different than other Leonard adaptations and is very entertaining. The dialogue seems to be straight from the books and the characters and the situations they find themselves in are hysterical. I recommend this show and the books Riding The Rap and Pronto if you want be a part of Deputy Marshall Givens' earlier adventures.

reviewText: I would think if you like Breaking Bad that you would like this.  At least, we do.  Like Breaking Bad this production has one quirky off beat character after the next.  Imaginative story line and good actors...very good.  If violence is going to bother you...pass...pass...pass.  I normally do not watch anything violent, but somehow I got through all of the gruesome scenes in Breaking Bad, which we thought was/is tremendous and although I may have to squint at times I am enjoying Justified. reviewText: A well written action series, takes Game of Thrones and sets it present day Eastern Kentucky.  I've lived most of my life in Eastern Kentucky, and have to say, the series exploits the ugliest stereotypes of Eastern Kentucky, but it is done in an interesting way.  Interesting plots, and good acting, if you like cop shows, you will probably like this.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: This dvd series is betrayed by the worst visuals experienced on a dvd.It looks like it was video taped from a TV set. The focus goes in and out throughout the "viewing experience" and is so prevalent that you wonder if it was shot like this originally. Shot being an interesting consideration for whoever is responsible for this mess.There is a telling moment in the prologue where Peter Green is about to be "justified" and the table he's sitting at has a pixilated blob in the right hand corner of the screen. I believe it's obscuring the FX logo. Which wouldn't appear in an original print, only some later (poorly made)copy.I've ordered this thing four times.The first used copy I received, I accused the store of sending me a Mexican bootleg (the store was located in Texas near the border).They were nice about it where I wasn't. And then the next one looked like the first and so on. I can tell you that a new unopened copy isn't any better.All of this sounds so dillitantish from a guy that used to watch black & white TV but it really does bother the crap out of me when you finally get a big flat screen and a Blu-ray player and it only magnifies the ineffectiveness of the medium you're using. There's probably a good story in there somewhere but I'm finding it too annoying to watch. Maybe a Mexican or Chinese bootleg would be better.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: We are a crime drama nation and when I saw still yet another crime drama rife with cliche's like cowboy hats, Kentucky jargon, and US Marshalls come along I hesitated to give it a try.  The pilot even begins with a cliche draw-and-shoot dramatic scene, but that's as far as this series goes to be cliche.  Right from the very first scene the writing and acting are perfectly in sync. The writers know the characters and the actors protray the writers scenes superbly.  Even though the introductory sub-plot is mandatorially covered in the pilot, it feels like an episode someplace in the second season it is done so well.  The pace of the show is set perfectly in the pilot as well, and it is kept uniform through season 1 without a hitch.  I get a strong feeling from watching this series it that not only are the character roles respected by the writers and actors, the viewer is given a strong respect as well.  That alone is refreshing in a crime drama.  This is not a cookie cutter show.This is no season launch with the actors fumbling around for character development either.  Each scene is portrayed and painstakingly blocked and depicted in detail - right down to the stenciled name on the prison sheets and the coal miner accents.  The show comes into our living rooms with just the right amount of personal touch.  Just two characters in a room talking will engage the viewer with believable dialogue - an outcome of numerous read-throughs and actors understanding their roles no doubt.The set detail, location shoots, and production quality are the very best on TV today.  The actors, writing and plots are well done and carefully avoid formulaic dramadies.  The lead (Timothy Olyphant) is well on his way to being a big big star with his work on this series.  (Ladies, check this guy out!)  But look out!  This series is as addicting as it is entertaining.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I love, love, love this show. Elmore Leonard brought to life, and well. It has just the right combo of violence, witty dialogue and heart.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Justified.Hmm..Well, originally I was lured by Tim Olyphant. I was hot for him in Deadwood, the unparalleled HBO Western. Justified is no Deadwood, and it's unfair of me to even compare. But there it is, and I had expectations. Deadwood is an impossible act to follow.In Justified, the premise is plausible, the writing is okay, not inescapably compelling, but good enough. I like Olyphant's character. He seems true, right. The other characters are also believable and the acting is good.I love some of the music- in fact I've fallen hard in love with Gangstagrass, a Hip-Hop/Bluegrass hybrid band responsible for the awesome theme song.All in all?It's okay; I like it.I don't rush home to see it, and if I never finished watching the first season, I would live. But it's good enough.
summary: Somewhere between "It's okay," and "I like it."
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: We are Elmore Leonard fans around here. This series brings a colorful illustration to Leonard's wit, humor, tension, action and a charming self-deprecating sexiness to Olyphant's Rayland.

reviewText: I'm a Southerner so may be biased, but Raylan's character is the perfect hero. & Boyd is the best antagonist. (I've been a fan of Timothy Oliphant quite a while but Walton Coggins is new to me. & I'm enthralled.) The series has many,many great characters.Check it out! reviewText: Justified is a little different than your average law and order type show.  Part of the charm is that it takes place in the Kentucky hills and is like a modern day Hatfield vs McCoy in some ways.  Raylan, the main character, is a very down-to-earth Marshall but is almost a vigilante at times.  There's some good comic relief and great characters in this show.

reviewText: My mother recommended this to me. I was skeptical, but after getting over the blatant stereotypes, I found myself enjoying it. I will admit that the first season took two viewings. It just took a while to get into it. Yet, after I did I really came to enjoy it.

Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I have watched this show from the pilot all the way thru to episode 11.  Each episode has been awesome and leaving me wondering what was going to happen next.  I do not watch a lot of TV but this is a show worth your time.  It is well written, and all the actors that play these characters have them portrayed dead-on perfect. I have to admit I love westerns and miss them being on TV but Justified is not a western.  Raylan Givens is an old-school lawman in modern day times and his way of law is "black & white" and Timothy Olyphant plays that character as if his birth certificate said "Raylan Givens". I am so glad FX picked up this show for a second season and I was hoping the fist season would come out on DVD.  This show deserves a bunch of awards and I hope to see it nominated.  You won't go wrong with this DVD.  I've seen the first 11 episodes and can't wait to see 12 & 13.  And I'm sure the finale' will be a huge cliff-hanger leaving us to wish March getting here soon so we can see what happens next.  Of all the junk that is on TV Timothy Olyphant and FX have given us true entertainment in Justified.  Don't miss out!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Unlike Sons of Anarchy or Breaking Bad, the good guys get their criminal in Justified, a serial story of the United States Marshals Service set in modern era Kentucky.  Parts of the show seem to have some poetic license - that's Hollywood.  I like that the good guy in the almost white hat rides victorious from episode to episode.  I like the AUSA (Assistant U.S. Attorney) David Vasquez and the Chief U. S. Deputy Marshal characters and of course the lead role, Raylan Givens played by Timothy Olyphant.  The criminals are true to life degenerates.  Fun show, nice distraction.  Free for Amazon Prime members.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: My wife and I started watching in Season 3. I'm glad we were able to go back on Amazon Prime and catch up!
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Terrible acting and story line. Place a hunk in an add and what do you get, folks looking just to view the hunk. I do not recommend this series unless you are simply bored with nothing else to watch
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: One of my college age sons encouraged me to watch Justified. I was reluctant to watch another cop show at first, but now we are hooked. The main character Raylan is full of flaws, often loses his battles but still tries to do the right thing. Set in the backwoods of rural Kentucky the story line centers around rural town life, distrust of strangers and long standing family feuds. The stories are well written and the acting is great - its easy to think the actors are really just the people in the story. Not for kids given the language, violence and adult themes. We are finishing season 2 and can't wait to see how the story progresses over the next few seasons.
summary: New twist on a cop show
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: great series dialog, pacing, variety -- must see. they've managed to get the flavor of Elmore Leonard down pat, cudos
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: I bought the Season 1 DVDs for my husband for Christmas, because he loved Deadwood, Elmore Leonard novels, and Westerns.  He could not stop raving about Justified, comparing it to his other all-time favorite show, The Wire.  So I started watching and was immediately hooked.  Here's why.  Although it's set in Kentucky, and the characters are self-professed "hillbillies," they are smartly written, clever and funny.  There are a few "Dukes of Hazzard" types -- but they are recognized as being dumb by the other characters, not put forward to the audience as the norm for people in this part of the country.  The bad guys, as in The Wire, are finely drawn; sometimes you root for them, other times, you cringe at how evil they are.  Walton Goggins' "Boyd" character is a prime example.  At first glance, you think he's some Aryan Nation dumb redneck who just likes to blow stuff up, but you quickly come to realize that he's MUCH more complex than that.  He has a "maybe redemption/maybe not" storyline all through Season One that is beautifully written.The star of the show, Timothy Olyphant, is brilliant, and his character is amazing. Raylan Givens is a great character:  also smart, flawed, sarcastic, and loyal, both to the US Marshal Service and to his hillbilly roots.  It's an exeptional show that has you rooting for both the lawman AND the villain.In terms of storyline, the series is clearly written by someone from Kentucky or a place like it.  The dialogue is authentic -- and often laugh out loud funny --  and the characters ring true.  The show is realistically violent, and because it's basic cable, the language is adult, but it's not gratuitous like something on HBO or Showtime.I'm deep into Season Two, and the quality is still terrific.  I like well-written, gritty, (fictonally) realistic crime shows like The Wire, and Breaking Bad.  Justified is right up there with those two shows.  Try the first episode, and you will be hooked.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: As a heartbroken fan of Nip/Tuck, which just ended its 6 season run, I was keeping an eye out for another FX show I could enjoy. With FX, original series can be either hit (Nip/Tuck, Dirt) or miss (The Riches). Justified is a show I normally wouldn't have looked at even once. Being a city girl at heart, I'm not a fan of westerns or anything country. One thing I am a fan of is Timothy Olyphant. When I saw one of my favorite actors (brilliant in "Hitman") was going to be in a new show, I of course had to watch. A pleasant surprise awaited me.It's as if Timothy Olyphant was born to be US Marshal Raylan Givens, a good ol' country boy with personal issues. After shooting a man in Miami old west style ("It was justified"), Raylan is punished by being sent back to his old home town in Kentucky to work the local cases, many involving people he knows. His estranged father, former best-friend-turned-criminal, an old flame and a complicated ex wife round out the engaging cast of colorful characters. Raylan has a reputation for being a bit trigger-happy, a branding he hardly thinks is fair ("only if it's justified"). He is never without his 10 gallon hat (unless someone steals it), he can talk down a hostage situation with whiskey and a bucket of fried chicken, or shoot a guy for "taking one more step". It's all in a day's work for Raylan.Justified is one of those shows that makes you forget you're watching a show being acted by actors. It's as though you are observing actual people live their lives. I feel like I'm in the scene, watching everything unfold before me. The dialogue is fresh, gritty, real and absolutely hilarious. The characters bounce between utterly ridiculous and completely relatable. And the actors, everyone from the main stars to the day players are right on the money.If you haven't yet seen Justified, do yourself a favor and catch it when it re-airs on FX. Watch it On Demand. Or wait for the DVD's to come out. If you don't give this show a chance, well, that ain't civilized.
Title: Justified: Season 1

reviewText: Well, it is set in Eastern Kentucky, rather then in Sparta, Mississippi; still, Justified is bound to resonate with any fan of the groundbreaking In the Heat of the Night series: small-town-in-a-big-World problems being solved creatively in 60 minutes or less, but without the annoyingly preachy tone that In the Heat of the Night would sometimes assume. A definite positive! You'll have fun making character comparisons between the two shows (can you find a "Bubba"? how about a "Luanne"?).Let me first note that Justified is a very new show; so far, only six episodes have been aired. However, the episodes carry such an unusually high degree of promise, I feel confident rating the series, even at this early stage, with the top score.The story is simple: deputy U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) brings too much negative attention to himself by killing one Miami thug too many... He is therefore relegated to a remote post to cool his heels. Unfortunately for Raylan, the post happens to be the sleepy Eastern Kentucky, where he grew up and hoped never to come back... Estranged petty criminal father, an ex-wife, an ex-flame, an ex-friend... Well... they do say you can never go back home... Or, was it: you SHOULD NEVER go back home?... Anyway, upon this background, the writers skillfully project a series of surprisingly engaging, multidimensional stories that go beyond catching "the baddy of the week." Yes, there is the usual parade of rednecks (and I hope we'll get to see more eccentric types as time progresses), but often "the baddies" are portrayed as flawed human beings, making some very poor choices, all while doing their best to survive in this World. And that does have the effect of bringing them into conflict with the law.Also satisfying is the way the writers choose to characterize Raylan: he is NOT some cartoon super hero using secret kung fu moves to dispatch his enemies. Instead, he is a humble man, still dealing with emotional ramifications of his divorce, and still conflicted in his relationship with his father. Occasionally, he allows his foes to gain the upper hand (and rob him of his car, badge, and gun), further proving he is a real person, which makes him very relatable... Kudos to Timothy Olyphant for his portrayal of Givens. Both he and the writers have the character spot on from the first minute of the pilot!To those who like action though, worry NOT. The stories never get sappy and there is plenty of creative a** kicking (somehow, even a bazooka makes it into the script!). If I were forced to find a pet peeve regarding Justified, it would probably be the unrealistically high number of good looking people with porcelain veneers and slim waistlines the authors have inhabiting the area. From my personal experience involving a five week stay in Lexington, Kentucky, the reality has fewer teeth and a much higher BMI (no offence to the locals intended ;o) ).And so, keep this show on your radar. I don't watch TV anymore (I have cancelled my cable as it seems to stream nothing more then vile reality shows), but am so enthused by Justified, that I actually pay to watch it on Amazon On Demand... Go figure...
summary: A.k.a.: "In the Heat of the Night, the Kentucky Edition"...

Raylin is a favorite personality of ours now and we are currently looking up other movies that Tim Olyphant stars in so we can see them also.
